mistralai/Mistral-Large-3-675B-Instruct-2512

+ Mythology-Inspired — Gods Wore Sneakers (Chapter Avg: 55.5 | Final: 41.3)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Mythology-Inspired Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Gods wore sneakers.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Mythology-Inspired Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Gods wore sneakers. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# **Writing Plan: *Gods Wore Sneakers*** ## **Brainstorming** ### **Core Concept & Themes** - **Literal Interpretation:** Gods (from any pantheon) exist in the modern world but have adapted to contemporary life—specifically, they wear sneakers instead of sandals or bare feet. - **Metaphorical Interpretation:** The "gods" could be modern figures (celebrities, athletes, influencers, tech moguls) who are treated like deities, and their sneakers symbolize their earthly, commercialized divinity. - **Tone & Style:** - **Comedic/Satirical:** Gods struggling with modern life (e.g., Zeus trying to use a smartphone, Odin dealing with DMV bureaucracy). - **Urban Fantasy:** Gods hiding in plain sight, using sneakers to blend in (e.g., Hermes as a bike courier, Athena as a corporate strategist). - **Mythic Retelling:** A classic myth (e.g., the Odyssey, Ragnarök, the Mahabharata) but set in the modern world with gods in sneakers. - **Coming-of-Age:** A mortal discovers they’re the child of a god and must navigate a world where divinity is casual (e.g., Nike sneakers as a status symbol among gods). - **Possible Settings:** - A high school where the popular kids are secretly gods. - A corporate office where the CEO is actually Hades. - A sports league where the star players are divine beings. - A streetwear brand run by gods (e.g., "Olympus Kicks"). - A post-apocalyptic world where sneakers are the last relics of the old gods. ### **Character Ideas** - **Protagonist:** - A mortal who discovers they’re the child of a god (or a god in disguise). - A god who has fallen out of favor and is trying to regain their power. - A human who worships sneakers as sacred objects, not realizing they’re tied to real gods. - A sneaker designer who accidentally summons a god by creating a legendary shoe. - **Supporting Gods:** - **Zeus** – A retired basketball star who still thinks he’s the best. - **Athena** – A sneakerhead who runs a reselling empire. - **Anubis** – A sneaker authenticator who judges the dead by their shoe collection. - **Loki** – A trickster who runs a fake sneaker drop scam. - **Hermes** – A delivery driver who still moves at supernatural speed. - **Freya** – A fashion influencer who blesses (or curses) outfits. - **Shiva** – A breakdancer who destroys sneakers as part of his art. - **Quetzalcoatl** – A sneaker designer who creates shoes that let people fly. - **Antagonists:** - A mortal who has stolen divine sneakers and gained godlike power. - A corporation that has imprisoned gods to harvest their divine essence for shoes. - A forgotten god trying to erase sneaker culture to restore "true" worship. - A rival pantheon (e.g., Norse vs. Greek gods in a sneaker battle). ### **Plot Ideas** 1. **The Sneaker Prophecy:** - A rare pair of sneakers is said to grant godhood to whoever wears them. Mortals and gods alike scramble to find them, leading to a modern-day divine war fought in sneakerhead forums and resale shops. 2. **Gods in Exile:** - The gods have been banished to Earth and must live as mortals, but their divine nature leaks out in strange ways (e.g., Ares starts street fights, Aphrodite makes people fall in love with shoes). 3. **The Last Sneakerhead:** - In a world where sneakers are the last remnants of the gods, a young collector must protect them from a cult that wants to burn them to "free" humanity from divine influence. 4. **The Sneaker Games:** - A modern take on the Olympic Games, but instead of sports, gods compete in sneaker battles (e.g., fastest resale, best custom design, most hyped drop). 5. **The God Who Forgot:** - A god (e.g., Odin) wakes up with amnesia and thinks he’s just a sneakerhead. His memories slowly return as he encounters other gods in disguise. 6. **The Sneaker Apocalypse:** - A pair of cursed sneakers starts turning people into mindless sneaker zombies. The gods must team up to stop the spread before the world is consumed by hype. 7. **The Divine Resale:** - A mortal accidentally buys a pair of sneakers that are actually the shoes of a god. Now, the god’s enemies are after them, and the mortal must return them before they’re cursed. 8. **The Sneaker Covenant:** - A secret society of sneakerheads is actually a modern cult worshipping the old gods. When a new member discovers their rituals involve real magic, they must decide whether to embrace their divinity or expose the truth. ### **Chapter-by-Chapter Pacing Ideas** - **Slow Burn (Mystery/Discovery):** - Ch. 1: Introduce protagonist in a mundane setting (e.g., a sneaker convention, a dead-end retail job). - Ch. 2: Strange occurrences hint at something supernatural (e.g., a shoe that never gets dirty, a customer who pays in ancient coins). - Ch. 3: First direct encounter with a god (e.g., a homeless man who knows too much, a street artist who never ages). - Ch. 4: Protagonist learns the truth—gods exist, and sneakers are their modern relics. - Ch. 5: A minor god offers help, but at a cost. - Ch. 6: The antagonist is revealed (e.g., a rival god, a mortal who has stolen divine power). - Ch. 7: The protagonist must make a choice—embrace their own divinity or reject it. - Ch. 8: Climactic showdown (e.g., a sneaker battle, a race to reclaim a stolen shoe, a ritual to restore the gods). - **Fast-Paced (Action/Comedy):** - Ch. 1: A god (e.g., Hermes) is working a dead-end delivery job when he’s summoned to Olympus—only to find it’s been turned into a sneaker warehouse. - Ch. 2: The gods are in chaos because someone has stolen Zeus’ favorite Jordans. - Ch. 3: Hermes is sent to Earth to retrieve them, but the thief is a mortal who doesn’t know the shoes are divine. - Ch. 4: A chase ensues through a sneaker convention, with gods and mortals clashing over the shoes. - Ch. 5: The thief accidentally puts on the shoes and gains godlike speed, leading to a high-stakes race. - Ch. 6: The other gods get involved, each trying to claim the shoes for themselves. - Ch. 7: Hermes realizes the shoes were never the real problem—it’s the corporate entity that’s been siphoning divine power. - Ch. 8: The gods team up to take down the corporation in a final, over-the-top battle (e.g., a sneaker drop gone wrong, a divine sneaker smackdown). ### **Worldbuilding Details** - **Divine Sneakers:** - Each god has a signature shoe (e.g., Zeus’ Air Jordans, Athena’s Air Force 1s, Hades’ all-black Yeezys). - Wearing a god’s sneakers grants temporary powers (e.g., Hermes’ shoes make you fast, Aphrodite’s make you irresistible). - Some sneakers are cursed (e.g., Ares’ shoes make you aggressive, Eris’ cause chaos). - **Modern Worship:** - Sneakerheads are the new priests, resale shops are temples, and sneaker conventions are religious gatherings. - Social media is the new oracle—gods communicate through memes and hypebeast culture. - **Divine Rules:** - Gods can’t interfere directly in mortal affairs unless someone wears their shoes. - The more people believe in a god, the stronger they become (e.g., a god with a viral sneaker brand is nearly invincible). - Mortals who wear divine sneakers too long risk becoming gods themselves—or burning out. --- ## **Reflection** ### **What Works?** 1. **The Premise is Fresh & Fun:** - The idea of gods wearing sneakers is inherently humorous and visually striking. It’s a great way to modernize mythology without losing its essence. - The contrast between ancient divinity and modern consumerism is rich with satirical potential (e.g., gods arguing over resale value, worshipping sneaker drops like sacred events). 2. **Flexible Tone & Genre:** - The concept can work as **comedy** (gods struggling with modern life), **urban fantasy** (hidden gods in the city), **action** (divine sneaker battles), or even **horror** (cursed shoes that consume the wearer). - This flexibility means the story can appeal to different audiences. 3. **Strong Character Potential:** - Gods as flawed, relatable figures (e.g., a washed-up Zeus, a sneakerhead Athena) make for great dynamic characters. - Mortal protagonists can serve as audience surrogates, discovering the divine world alongside the reader. 4. **Thematic Depth:** - Explores **divinity in the modern world** (What does it mean to be a god when no one believes in you?). - Critiques **consumerism and fandom** (Are sneakerheads the new religious zealots?). - Questions **identity and power** (Can a mortal handle godhood? What happens when gods become too human?). 5. **Pacing & Structure Options:** - The **mystery/slow burn** approach is great for a more literary or introspective take. - The **action/comedy** approach is perfect for a fast-paced, bingeable story. - Both allow for a satisfying arc over 8 chapters. ### **What Doesn’t Work? (Or Needs Refinement)** 1. **Risk of Being Too Silly:** - If the story leans too hard into comedy, it might lose emotional weight. Gods in sneakers is funny, but if it’s *only* funny, it won’t feel like a complete story. - **Solution:** Balance humor with genuine stakes (e.g., a god losing their power, a mortal facing a divine curse). 2. **Overcomplicating the Mythology:** - If every god from every pantheon is included, the story could become cluttered. - **Solution:** Focus on a core group (e.g., Greek gods, or a mix of Norse and Egyptian) and use others as cameos. 3. **Sneakers as a Gimmick:** - If the sneakers are just a visual joke and don’t drive the plot, the story might feel shallow. - **Solution:** Make the sneakers **central** to the conflict (e.g., they’re the source of power, the key to a prophecy, or the reason gods are trapped on Earth). 4. **Mortal Protagonist Clichés:** - The "chosen one" trope (e.g., a mortal discovers they’re the child of a god) is overused. - **Solution:** Subvert expectations—maybe the protagonist is already a god but doesn’t know it, or they’re an antagonist trying to steal divine power. 5. **Pacing Challenges:** - If the story starts too slow, readers might lose interest before the supernatural elements kick in. - **Solution:** Introduce **one** weird element in the first chapter (e.g., a shoe that never wears out, a stranger who knows the protagonist’s future). ### **Potential Directions to Explore Further** 1. **The Sneaker Prophecy (Urban Fantasy/Mystery):** - A rare pair of sneakers is said to grant godhood. Mortals and gods race to find them, leading to a mix of heists, betrayals, and divine interventions. - **Why it works:** High stakes, clear goal, room for twists (e.g., the shoes are a trap, the real prophecy is different). 2. **Gods in Exile (Comedy/Drama):** - The gods have been banished to Earth and must live as mortals, but their divine natures cause chaos (e.g., Ares starts fights, Aphrodite breaks hearts, Hermes can’t stop stealing). - **Why it works:** Fish-out-of-water humor with emotional depth (gods struggling with mortality). 3. **The Divine Resale (Action/Heist):** - A mortal accidentally buys a pair of divine sneakers and must return them before the gods come after them. - **Why it works:** Fast-paced, high-energy, and the sneakers are directly tied to the conflict. 4. **The Sneaker Apocalypse (Horror/Dystopian):** - A cursed pair of sneakers turns people into mindless sneaker zombies. The gods must team up to stop the spread. - **Why it works:** Dark, unique take on the prompt with a clear antagonist (the shoes themselves). ### **Final Thoughts** The best version of this story will: - **Balance humor and heart** (gods in sneakers is funny, but there should be real stakes). - **Make the sneakers matter** (they’re not just a joke—they drive the plot). - **Give the protagonist agency** (they’re not just along for the ride; their choices matter). - **Explore a fresh angle on mythology** (not just a retelling, but a new take). **Next Steps:** - Decide on **tone** (comedy, urban fantasy, horror, etc.). - Choose **core characters** (protagonist, main gods, antagonist). - Outline **key plot beats** (what’s the inciting incident? The midpoint twist? The climax?). - Develop **worldbuilding rules** (how do divine sneakers work? What are the consequences of wearing them?). Would you like to narrow down a specific direction for the outline? (e.g., comedy, urban fantasy, horror, etc.)
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# **Intention** ### **Core Concept & Thematic Focus** This story will be an **urban fantasy-comedy** with **satirical and mythological depth**, exploring the idea of **gods existing in the modern world—not as lofty, distant figures, but as flawed, relatable beings who have adapted to contemporary life by wearing sneakers**. The sneakers are not just a gimmick; they are **divine artifacts that retain (or distort) the gods’ powers**, and their presence in the mortal world creates conflict, humor, and unexpected consequences. The story will **avoid** the following: - **Overly silly or shallow humor** (e.g., gods doing nothing but modern-day slapstick). Instead, the comedy will come from **character-driven interactions** (e.g., a god struggling with bureaucracy, a mortal realizing their favorite sneakerhead is actually a deity). - **A "chosen one" protagonist** (e.g., a mortal discovering they’re the child of a god). Instead, the protagonist will be **a mortal who stumbles into the divine world by accident**, forcing them to navigate it without the safety net of destiny. - **Overcomplicating the mythology**. The story will focus on **a small group of gods** (primarily Greek, with a few Norse or Egyptian cameos) to keep the worldbuilding tight and the stakes clear. - **Making the sneakers irrelevant to the plot**. The sneakers will be **central to the conflict**—either as a source of power, a curse, or a key to restoring the gods’ status. The story will **aim for** the following: - **A balance of humor and heart**. The gods’ struggles with modernity will be funny, but their **existential crises** (e.g., losing their worshippers, being forgotten, or becoming too human) will add emotional weight. - **A fast-paced, bingeable structure**. Each chapter will **end with a hook** to keep the reader engaged, and the plot will escalate steadily toward a climactic showdown. - **A fresh take on mythology**. Instead of retelling a classic myth, the story will **reimagine gods in a modern setting** (e.g., Hermes as a delivery driver, Athena as a corporate strategist, Ares as a gym bro). - **A protagonist with agency**. The main character will **drive the plot through their choices**, not just react to divine shenanigans. - **Thematic depth**. The story will explore **faith in the modern world** (What does it mean to worship something? Who gets to decide what’s sacred?), **consumerism as religion** (Are sneakerheads the new cults?), and **the cost of divinity** (What happens when gods become too human?). --- ### **Plot & Stylistic Choices** - **Plot Structure:** A **heist/mystery hybrid** with **divine stakes**. The story will revolve around a **rare pair of sneakers** that are actually the lost shoes of a god, and the race to reclaim (or destroy) them. The sneakers grant power to whoever wears them, but at a cost—**the longer a mortal wears them, the more they risk becoming a god (or losing their humanity)**. - **Protagonist:** **Jace Morales**, a 22-year-old sneaker reseller who accidentally buys the divine shoes at a thrift store. He’s not special—just a guy who loves sneakers and wants to make a quick buck. His **lack of reverence for the divine** (he treats the shoes like any other rare pair) is what makes him the perfect (and dangerous) candidate to wear them. - **Antagonist:** **The Fade**, a forgotten god (originally a minor deity of lost things) who has been **erasing divine artifacts** to force the gods back into obscurity. He sees sneakers as the ultimate symbol of the gods’ corruption—**they’ve traded worship for hype, faith for fashion**. - **Tone:** **Witty, fast-paced, and slightly irreverent**, but with **emotional moments** (e.g., a god realizing no one remembers them, a mortal struggling with the weight of divinity). Think *American Gods* meets *Scott Pilgrim*, with the energy of a sneakerhead YouTube channel. - **Narrative Voice:** **Third-person limited**, focusing on Jace’s perspective. The narration will be **sharp and observational**, with a dry sense of humor. Dialogue will be **snappy and modern**, with gods slipping into archaic speech when emotional or angry. - **Worldbuilding Rules:** - **Divine Sneakers:** Each pair is tied to a god’s domain (e.g., Zeus’ Air Jordans grant storm manipulation, Hades’ Yeezys let you phase through shadows). Wearing them too long **warps the wearer’s mind**—they start thinking like the god, losing their mortal identity. - **Modern Worship:** The more people **desire** a sneaker, the stronger the god it’s tied to becomes. Sneaker conventions are the new temples, resale shops are sacred ground, and hypebeasts are the new priests. - **The Fade’s Curse:** The Fade can **erase divine items** by touching them, but doing so **drains his own power**. He’s been doing this for centuries, and he’s running out of time—if he doesn’t destroy the last of the gods’ relics (the sneakers), he’ll disappear forever. --- ### **Stakes & Character Arcs** - **Jace’s Arc:** Starts as a **cynical, self-interested sneaker reseller** who sees the shoes as a payday. By the end, he must **choose between his humanity and godhood**—does he keep the power, or return the shoes to stop The Fade? - **The Gods’ Arc:** The gods are **weakened, forgotten, and desperate**. They’ve been **relying on sneaker hype to sustain themselves**, but The Fade’s erasures are cutting off their power. They must **reclaim their relics or fade into obscurity**. - **The Fade’s Arc:** A **tragic antagonist**—he was once worshipped, but now he’s **erasing the last traces of the gods to force them to remember what it means to be divine**. His goal is **not evil, but misguided**; he thinks he’s saving the gods from themselves. --- ### **Key Scenes to Include** 1. **The Thrift Store Find:** Jace buys the sneakers, not knowing they’re divine. The first hint of their power comes when he **accidentally uses them to escape a mugging** (e.g., his speed increases, he phases through a wall). 2. **The First God Encounter:** Hermes (disguised as a delivery driver) confronts Jace, demanding the shoes back. Their **clash of personalities** (Hermes is fast-talking and chaotic, Jace is skeptical and sarcastic) sets the tone for the story. 3. **The Sneaker Convention:** A **chaotic, neon-lit battle** where gods and mortals clash over the shoes. Think *John Wick* but with sneakerheads. 4. **The Fade’s Introduction:** Jace meets The Fade, who **erases a pair of divine sneakers right in front of him**, leaving only a scorch mark. The Fade warns him: *"You’re holding a god’s last breath."* 5. **The Cost of Power:** Jace starts **hearing voices** (the god whose shoes he’s wearing) and experiences **flashes of their memories**. He realizes he’s **losing himself**. 6. **The Final Choice:** Jace must **decide whether to keep the shoes** (and become a god) or **return them to stop The Fade**. The gods offer him a place among them, but at what cost? --- ### **What to Avoid** - **Making the gods too powerful**. They should be **strong, but not invincible**—their power wanes if no one believes in them. - **A predictable ending**. The story should **subvert expectations**—maybe Jace doesn’t become a god, or maybe The Fade’s plan succeeds in an unexpected way. - **Over-explaining the rules**. The worldbuilding should be **discovered naturally** through character interactions, not info-dumps. - **Making Jace a passive protagonist**. He should **drive the plot**, not just react to the gods’ schemes. --- # **Chapter Planning** ### **Chapter 1: The Thrift Store Find** - **Opening Scene:** Jace Morales, a struggling sneaker reseller, browses a thrift store looking for hidden gems. He’s **cynical, broke, and desperate**—his last resale fell through, and he’s behind on rent. - **The Discovery:** He finds a **pristine pair of vintage sneakers** (later revealed to be Hermes’ winged sandals, reimagined as a rare Nike collab). The store owner, an old man with **unnervingly sharp eyes**, sells them to him for $20. - **First Sign of Power:** On his way home, Jace is **mugged by a group of teens**. In a panic, he **runs faster than he ever has**, leaving them in the dust. He chalks it up to adrenaline. - **Hook:** He gets home and **notices the shoes are glowing faintly** in the dark. Before he can investigate, his phone buzzes—**a notification from a sneaker app: "RARE NIKE X HERMES COLLAB DETECTED NEAR YOU."** - **Ending:** Jace dismisses it as a glitch, but when he checks the app again, **everyone in his city is suddenly searching for the same shoes**. --- ### **Chapter 2: The Delivery Driver** - **Jace’s Dilemma:** He lists the shoes online for **$10,000**, but before he can sell them, he gets a **mysterious DM**: *"Those aren’t for sale. Meet me at the old subway station. Alone."* - **The Encounter:** Jace goes to the station, where he meets **a fast-talking delivery driver** (Hermes in disguise). Hermes **recognizes the shoes immediately** and demands them back. - **The Chase:** Jace refuses, and Hermes **loses his temper**, revealing his **supernatural speed**. Jace barely escapes, but not before Hermes **slips a business card into his pocket**: *"Call me when you realize what you’re holding."* - **The First Cost:** Jace gets home and **notices his reflection is flickering**—for a second, he sees **a winged figure in the mirror**. - **Hook:** His phone buzzes again—this time, **a news alert: "LOCAL MAN REPORTED MISSING AFTER BUYING 'CURSED' SNEAKERS."** The article includes a blurry photo of **the old man from the thrift store**. --- ### **Chapter 3: The Sneaker Convention** - **The Hype:** Jace decides to **sell the shoes at a local sneaker convention**, where he can get the best price. The convention is **packed with collectors, resellers, and influencers**—all obsessed with rare kicks. - **The Gods Arrive:** Unbeknownst to Jace, **the convention is a gathering place for gods in disguise**. Athena (a corporate strategist), Ares (a gym bro), and Dionysus (a party promoter) are all there, **searching for the shoes**. - **The Auction:** Jace puts the shoes up for auction, and the **bidding war turns violent**. Ares **starts a fight**, Dionysus **spikes the punch**, and Athena **hacks the bidding system** to win. - **The Escape:** Jace **snatches the shoes back** and runs, but not before **The Fade appears**—a **tall, gaunt figure in a tattered hoodie**—and **erases a pair of sneakers right in front of him**, leaving only a **scorch mark on the floor**. - **Hook:** As Jace flees, **Hermes appears beside him in a car**. *"Get in. We need to talk."* --- ### **Chapter 4: The Truth About the Shoes** - **The Ride:** Hermes takes Jace to an **abandoned church** (now a sneaker storage unit) and **explains the truth**: - The shoes are **Hermes’ winged sandals**, reimagined as sneakers. They grant **supernatural speed and agility**, but **the longer a mortal wears them, the more they risk becoming a god**. - The Fade is **erasing divine relics** to force the gods back into obscurity. If he destroys the shoes, **Hermes will lose his power permanently**. - **Jace’s Refusal:** Jace **doesn’t believe him** at first, but then Hermes **shows him a vision**—Jace sees **Hermes’ memories: the fall of Olympus, the gods scattering, the sneakers being lost**. - **The Offer:** Hermes asks Jace to **return the shoes**, but Jace **refuses**—he needs the money. Hermes warns him: *"The shoes will change you. And not in a good way."* - **Hook:** As Jace leaves, **The Fade appears in the rearview mirror**. *"You’re running out of time, little thief."* --- ### **Chapter 5: The First Transformation** - **The Voices:** Jace starts **hearing whispers** in his head—**Hermes’ voice, urging him to run faster, to never stop moving**. He **ignores them at first**, but the whispers grow louder. - **The Power Trip:** He **uses the shoes to win a street race**, earning **$5,000 in cash**. For the first time in months, he feels **invincible**. - **The Cost:** After the race, he **collapses**. When he looks in the mirror, **his eyes are glowing gold**. His reflection **winks at him**. - **The Warning:** Hermes tracks him down again. *"You’re changing. The shoes are bonding to you. If you keep wearing them, you’ll become one of us."* - **The Choice:** Jace **doesn’t care**—he’s **too addicted to the power**. But then he sees **a news report: The Fade has erased another divine item, and a god has vanished**. - **Hook:** Jace realizes **he’s not just risking his humanity—he’s risking the gods’ existence**. --- ### **Chapter 6: The Gods’ Last Stand** - **The Gathering:** The gods **convene in an abandoned sneaker warehouse** (their new "Olympus"). They’re **weak, divided, and desperate**. - **Zeus** (a retired basketball star) wants to **storm The Fade’s hideout**. - **Athena** wants to **negotiate**. - **Ares** just wants to **fight something**. - **The Plan:** Hermes suggests **using Jace as bait**—if they can get the shoes back, they can **restore their power**. The gods **agree, reluctantly**. - **The Betrayal:** Jace **overhears their plan** and **realizes they don’t care about him**—they just want the shoes. He **steals a pair of Zeus’ sneakers** (which grant **storm manipulation**) and **escapes**. - **The Fade’s Move:** The Fade **appears before Jace** and offers him a deal: *"Give me the shoes, and I’ll let you keep your humanity."* - **Hook:** Jace **hesitates**—but then he **sees his reflection again**, and this time, **it smiles back at him**. --- ### **Chapter 7: The Final Race** - **The Chase:** The gods **realize Jace has betrayed them** and **give chase**. Hermes is **furious**, but Athena **understands**—Jace is **scared, not evil**. - **The Showdown:** Jace **uses Zeus’ sneakers to summon a storm**, but **The Fade erases them mid-air**, leaving him **powerless**. The gods **corner him**. - **The Revelation:** The Fade **reveals his true plan**—he’s not trying to destroy the gods, he’s trying to **force them to remember what it means to be divine**. *"You’ve forgotten your purpose. You’ve become **hypebeasts**."* - **Jace’s Choice:** Jace realizes **The Fade is right**—the gods **have lost their way**. But he also knows **erasing the shoes won’t fix anything**. - **Hook:** He **makes a decision**—one that will **change everything**. --- ### **Chapter 8: The New Pantheon** - **The Sacrifice:** Jace **returns the shoes to Hermes**, but **not before using them one last time**—he **runs so fast he phases out of reality**, leaving behind **a single, glowing sneaker**. - **The Aftermath:** - The gods **regain their power**, but **they’re different now**—they’ve **remembered what it means to be worshipped**. - The Fade **disappears**, his mission complete. - Jace **wakes up in his apartment**, unsure if it was all a dream—until he sees **a single winged sneaker on his shelf**. - **The New Era:** The gods **return to the world**, but this time, they **don’t hide**. Athena **opens a sneaker empire**, Hermes **starts a delivery app**, and Zeus **hosts a basketball tournament**. - **The Twist:** In the final scene, **Jace gets a DM from an unknown number**: *"Nice shoes. Where’d you get them?"* The camera pans to **a pair of scuffed, winged sneakers** in a thrift store window. - **Ending:** Jace **smiles**. *"Some things are worth more than money."* --- ### **Final Notes** - **Pacing:** Each chapter **ends with a hook** to keep the reader engaged. - **Character Arcs:** Jace **starts as a cynic and ends as a believer**, the gods **rediscover their purpose**, and The Fade **gets his wish—but at a cost**. - **Themes:** **Faith vs. consumerism, the cost of power, and what it means to be divine in a modern world**. - **Tone:** **Fast, funny, and slightly melancholic**—like a sneakerhead’s dream with a touch of existential dread. Would you like any adjustments to the chapter breakdowns or the overall arc?
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
### **How a Human Might Approach This Piece (vs. LLM Tendencies)** Writing *"Gods Wore Sneakers"* as a human—especially one with a sharp, contemporary voice—would likely involve **messier, more idiosyncratic choices** than an LLM’s default approach. Below, I’ll break down: 1. **Common LLM Writing Pitfalls** (and why they might weaken this story). 2. **How a Human Writer Might Differ** (and why it would make the story stronger). 3. **A Deep Dive on the Current Plan’s LLM-Like Traps** (and how to humanize it). 4. **Brainstorming More Human Alternatives** (to avoid clichés, over-polish, and artificiality). --- ## **1. Common LLM Writing Pitfalls (And Why They’re a Problem Here)** LLMs tend to default to **safe, formulaic, or overly polished** writing because: - They’re trained on **published (i.e., already edited) work**, which often smooths out raw edges. - They **avoid risk**—no awkward phrasing, no unresolved threads, no ambiguity. - They **prioritize "completeness"** over **emotional truth** (e.g., tying up every loose end neatly). - They **over-explain** (because they’re designed to be clear, not mysterious). - They **lack personal voice** (because they average out styles rather than commit to one). For a story like *Gods Wore Sneakers*—which thrives on **humor, subversion, and modern irreverence**—these tendencies could **sap its vitality**. ### **Key LLM Pitfalls & Why They Matter for This Story** | **Pitfall** | **Why It’s Bad for This Story** | **Example in *Gods Wore Sneakers*** | |---------------------------|--------------------------------|------------------------------------| | **Over-polished prose** | Makes the writing feel **sterile and corporate**, killing the **gritty, street-level humor** the premise needs. | LLM: *"The sneakers hummed with latent divinity, their soles thrumming with the echoes of ancient power."* (Too pretty, too vague.) <br> Human: *"The shoes buzzed like a phone on silent. Jace kicked them off. They kept vibrating."* (Specific, weird, real.) | | **Tying everything up neatly** | Mythology is **messy, ambiguous, and cyclical**. A neat ending **undermines the theme of forgotten gods and fleeting faith**. | LLM: *"The gods returned to Olympus, stronger than ever, and Jace became a legend among them."* (Too tidy, too heroic.) <br> Human: *"The gods went back to their lives. Jace kept reselling sneakers. Sometimes, when he was drunk, he swore he saw a winged logo in a thrift store window."* (Open-ended, bittersweet.) | | **Avoiding awkwardness** | Gods in sneakers **should feel weird, not seamless**. Awkwardness is **funny and human**. | LLM: *"Hermes adjusted his delivery cap, his eyes flickering with divine amusement."* (Too smooth, too knowing.) <br> Human: *"Hermes took off his cap, scratched his head, and put it back on crooked. ‘So, uh. You ever hear of winged sandals?’"* (Clumsy, real, funny.) | | **Over-explaining the rules** | Urban fantasy works best when **the world feels lived-in, not like a textbook**. Too many rules **kill mystery and spontaneity**. | LLM: *"The shoes’ power was tied to belief—each time a mortal desired them, the god’s strength grew by 12.7%."* (Too clinical.) <br> Human: *"The more people wanted the shoes, the louder the whispers in Jace’s head got. He didn’t know if that was good or bad."* (Vague, unsettling, immersive.) | | **Protagonist as a "chosen one"** | Jace should feel **real, not like a video game hero**. A human writer would **let him fail, make bad choices, and not always "get it."** | LLM: *"Jace realized he was the key to saving the gods—he just had to embrace his destiny."* (Too heroic, too obvious.) <br> Human: *"Jace Googled ‘how to sell cursed shoes’ and found a Reddit thread from 2012. The top comment was just ‘lol don’t.’"* (Relatable, funny, not destiny-driven.) | | **Dialogue that’s too "on the nose"** | Gods in sneakers should **clash with modern slang, not sound like they’ve been media-trained**. | LLM: *"‘You mortals and your obsession with material possessions,’ Hermes sighed, shaking his head."* (Too moralizing, too polished.) <br> Human: *"‘Dude,’ Hermes said, ‘you’re gonna sell these for, what, ten grand? I used to deliver *messages* for that kind of cash.’"* (Funny, specific, human.) | | **Avoiding subtext** | LLMs **state emotions explicitly** because they’re trained to be clear. But **great writing implies more than it says**. | LLM: *"Jace felt a deep loneliness, like he didn’t belong in either world."* (Too direct.) <br> Human: *"Jace scrolled through his phone. His last text to his mom was ‘yeah I’m good’ from three weeks ago. The gods didn’t text."* (Shows loneliness without saying it.) | --- ## **2. How a Human Writer Might Approach This Differently** A human writer—especially one with a **sharp, contemporary, or subversive voice**—would likely: ### **A. Embrace the Weirdness (Instead of Sanding It Down)** - **LLM:** Tries to make the premise feel **plausible and grand**. - **Human:** Leans into **how *stupid* and *cool* it is** that gods wear sneakers. - Example: - LLM: *"The sneakers were a relic of Hermes’ divinity, their soles imbued with the essence of his speed."* - Human: *"The shoes had wings on the sides. Not, like, *metaphorical* wings. Actual little feathered wings that fluttered when he ran. Jace had worn them for three days before he noticed."* ### **B. Let the Characters Be Flawed (Instead of Heroic or Villainous)** - **LLM:** Makes Jace **the "reluctant hero"** and The Fade **the "misunderstood villain."** - **Human:** Lets Jace **be selfish, petty, and wrong**—and The Fade **be sympathetic but still dangerous**. - Example: - LLM: *"Jace realized the gods needed him. He couldn’t let them down."* - Human: *"Jace Googled ‘how to blackmail a god.’ The first result was a Quora thread titled ‘I tried this. Regret it.’"* ### **C. Use Humor That’s Specific (Instead of Generic)** - **LLM:** Defaults to **broad, safe jokes** (e.g., "Zeus was bad at using smartphones"). - **Human:** Uses **obsessive, niche, or absurd humor** (e.g., sneakerhead culture, godly pettiness, modern frustrations). - Example: - LLM: *"‘You mortals and your technology,’ Zeus grumbled, struggling with the self-checkout."* - Human: *"Zeus had been banned from three Foot Lockers for arguing with managers about ‘the sacred geometry of the Air Jordan 11.’"* ### **D. Leave Some Things Unresolved (Instead of Wrapping Everything Up)** - **LLM:** Wants **a clear moral, a happy ending, no loose threads**. - **Human:** Knows that **mythology is cyclical**—some things **shouldn’t be fixed**. - Example: - LLM: *"The gods returned to Olympus, and Jace became their mortal ambassador."* - Human: *"The gods went back to whatever gods do. Jace kept reselling sneakers. Sometimes, when he was drunk, he swore he saw a winged logo in a thrift store window. He never bought another pair."* ### **E. Make the World Feel Lived-In (Instead of Explained)** - **LLM:** **Info-dumps** the rules of the world (e.g., "Divine sneakers work like this..."). - **Human:** **Drips details naturally** through **character actions, dialogue, and weird observations**. - Example: - LLM: *"The shoes’ power was tied to belief—each time a mortal desired them, the god’s strength grew."* - Human: *"Jace listed the shoes on eBay. Within an hour, the bid was at $5,000. His hands started shaking. The shoes were warm. He took them off. They were still warm."* ### **F. Let the Protagonist Be Wrong (Instead of Always Right)** - **LLM:** Makes the protagonist **the smartest, most perceptive person in the room**. - **Human:** Lets the protagonist **misunderstand, panic, and make bad choices**. - Example: - LLM: *"Jace realized the shoes were dangerous. He had to return them."* - Human: *"Jace Googled ‘how to become a god.’ The first result was a WikiHow article titled ‘How to Become a God (According to Ancient Greeks).’ He clicked it."* --- ## **3. Deep Dive: Critiquing the Current Plan for LLM-Like Traps** The current plan is **strong**—it’s **fast-paced, funny, and thematically rich**—but it **risks falling into some LLM-like patterns**. Below, I’ll **highlight potential pitfalls** and **why they might weaken the story**. ### **A. The "Chosen One" Problem (Even If It’s Subverted)** - **Current Plan:** Jace is **an ordinary guy who stumbles into godhood**, but the story still **centers on him as the key to saving the gods**. - **Why It’s a Problem:** - Even if Jace **doesn’t want the role**, the fact that he’s **the only one who can fix things** still makes him feel like a **chosen one**. - **Mythology doesn’t need a "chosen one"**—it’s about **cycles, fate, and inevitability**. - **LLM Trap:** **Making the protagonist the linchpin of the plot**, even if they’re "reluctant." - **Human Alternative:** - What if **Jace isn’t special at all**? - What if **the shoes don’t *need* him**—they just **happen to bond with him**? - What if **the gods don’t actually care about him**—they just want the shoes back? ### **B. The "Neat Ending" Problem** - **Current Plan:** The gods **regain their power**, The Fade **disappears**, and Jace **gets a cool sneaker as a souvenir**. - **Why It’s a Problem:** - It’s **too tidy**. Mythology is **messy**—gods **don’t get happy endings**, they just **keep existing**. - The **theme of forgotten gods** is **undermined** if they all just **go back to normal**. - **LLM Trap:** **Wrapping everything up neatly** because "readers expect closure." - **Human Alternative:** - What if **the gods don’t get their power back fully**? - What if **Jace *does* become a god—but it’s awful**? - What if **The Fade wins, but it doesn’t fix anything**? ### **C. The "Over-Explained Rules" Problem** - **Current Plan:** Hermes **explains how the shoes work** in Chapter 4. - **Why It’s a Problem:** - **Mythology doesn’t explain itself**. The best urban fantasy **lets the reader piece things together**. - **Jace (and the reader) should be confused**—that’s **more fun** than a lecture. - **LLM Trap:** **Info-dumping** because "readers need to understand the rules." - **Human Alternative:** - What if **Hermes doesn’t know how the shoes work either**? - What if **the shoes behave differently for everyone**? - What if **Jace just Googles stuff and gets weird, contradictory answers**? ### **D. The "Dialogue That’s Too On the Nose" Problem** - **Current Plan:** Hermes says, *"The shoes will change you. And not in a good way."* - **Why It’s a Problem:** - It’s **too direct**. Gods **wouldn’t talk like therapists**—they’d be **cryptic, petty, or weird**. - **Modern dialogue should clash with divine speech** (e.g., a god saying *"Verily"* while Jace says *"Bro, what the hell?"*). - **LLM Trap:** **Making characters say exactly what they mean** for clarity. - **Human Alternative:** - Hermes: *"Dude, you ever see *The Fly*? It’s like that, but with more wings."* - Athena: *"You’re making a mistake. Also, your sneaker game is weak."* - The Fade: *"You think you’re the first mortal to wear those? You’re not. You’re just the first one who didn’t *scream*."* ### **E. The "Protagonist Who’s Too Competent" Problem** - **Current Plan:** Jace **figures out the shoes’ power quickly**, **escapes the gods**, and **makes a heroic choice at the end**. - **Why It’s a Problem:** - **Real people panic**. They **make bad choices**. They **don’t "figure it out"**—they **stumble through**. - **Jace should be in over his head**, not **the smartest guy in the room**. - **LLM Trap:** **Making the protagonist too capable** because "readers like competence." - **Human Alternative:** - What if **Jace keeps wearing the shoes because he’s addicted to the power**? - What if **he tries to sell them but gets scammed**? - What if **he accidentally summons a god by wearing the wrong shoes to a party**? ### **F. The "Villain With a Tragic Backstory" Problem** - **Current Plan:** The Fade is **a forgotten god trying to force the others to remember their purpose**. - **Why It’s a Problem:** - It’s **a little too neat**. **Real villains (and real gods) don’t have clean motives**. - **The Fade’s plan is too abstract**—why does erasing sneakers help? Why not **burn down a sneaker convention** or **possess a Nike executive**? - **LLM Trap:** **Giving the villain a "sympathetic" backstory** because "readers like complex villains." - **Human Alternative:** - What if **The Fade is just a bitter ex-god who got fired from Olympus**? - What if **he’s not trying to "save" the gods—he’s just pissed no one remembers him**? - What if **his plan is dumb, but he’s too stubborn to admit it**? --- ## **4. Brainstorming More Human Alternatives** Now, let’s **brainstorm ways to make the story feel more raw, weird, and human**—while keeping the **core premise intact**. ### **A. Make Jace More Flawed & Less "Special"** - **Current:** Jace is a **sneaker reseller who stumbles into godhood**. - **Human Twist:** - What if **Jace is a *failed* reseller**? (He’s in debt, his ex left him, his mom keeps asking when he’ll get a real job.) - What if **he doesn’t even *like* sneakers that much**? (He’s just in it for the money, but now he’s stuck in a divine mess.) - What if **he’s terrible at being a god**? (He tries to use his powers to win a street race but **crashes into a food truck**.) - What if **he keeps wearing the shoes even though they’re hurting him**? (Because he’s **addicted to the power**, not because he’s "the chosen one.") ### **B. Make the Gods More Petty & Less Wise** - **Current:** The gods are **weakened but still noble** (Athena is a corporate strategist, Hermes is a delivery driver). - **Human Twist:** - What if **the gods are *bad* at being human**? - Zeus **gets scammed by a timeshare salesman**. - Aphrodite **has a OnlyFans but no subscribers**. - Ares **keeps getting into bar fights he can’t win**. - What if **they’re not just weak—they’re *embarrassing***? - Hermes **gets fired from his delivery job for "suspicious activity"** (i.e., teleporting packages). - Athena **loses a court case because she keeps objecting "BY THE POWER OF OLYMPUS."** - What if **they’re not trying to "save the world"—they’re just trying to get by**? - Zeus **runs a basketball camp but keeps zapping kids with lightning**. - Hades **manages a nightclub but keeps accidentally sending people to the Underworld**. ### **C. Make the Sneakers Weirder & Less "Magical"** - **Current:** The sneakers **grant powers but come with a cost**. - **Human Twist:** - What if **the sneakers don’t work the same way twice**? - One day, they **make Jace run fast**. The next, they **make him invisible to security cameras**. The next, they **make his feet smell like ambrosia**. - What if **the shoes have *opinions***? - They **refuse to let Jace sell them**. - They **get mad if he wears socks**. - They **whisper insults** ("*You call that a jump shot? Pathetic.*"). - What if **the shoes are *cursed in mundane ways***? - They **never get dirty**, so Jace **can’t sell them as "used."** - They **always fit perfectly**, so he **can’t resell them to anyone else**. - They **attract pigeons**. ### **D. Make the Conflict More Messy & Less "Epic"** - **Current:** The Fade is **erasing divine relics to force the gods to remember their purpose**. - **Human Twist:** - What if **The Fade’s plan is *stupid* but he’s too stubborn to admit it**? - He’s been **erasing sneakers for centuries**, but the gods **just keep making new ones**. - His **big plan is to erase the last pair**, but **he doesn’t actually know what will happen**. - What if **The Fade isn’t even the real villain**? - Maybe **the real enemy is Nike** (who’s been **harvesting divine essence for years**). - Maybe **the shoes are sentient and *want* to be erased**. - What if **the conflict isn’t about "saving the gods"—it’s about Jace saving himself**? - The gods **don’t care if they disappear**—they’re **bored of eternity**. - Jace is the **only one who wants to stop The Fade** because **he’s the one who’ll lose his humanity**. ### **E. Make the Ending More Ambiguous & Less "Happy"** - **Current:** The gods **regain their power**, The Fade **disappears**, Jace **gets a cool souvenir**. - **Human Twist:** - What if **the gods don’t get their power back**? - They **adapt**. They **find new ways to be worshipped** (Zeus starts a **sneaker-themed cult**, Athena writes a **self-help book**). - What if **Jace *does* become a god—but it sucks**? - He **misses being human**. - The other gods **bully him** for being a "newb." - He **tries to quit but can’t**. - What if **The Fade wins—but it doesn’t fix anything**? - The gods **forget their purpose**, but **nothing changes**. - The sneakers **keep existing**, but **no one remembers why they’re special**. - Jace **keeps wearing them**, but **they don’t do anything anymore**. - What if **the story ends with a *new* mystery**? - Jace **finds another pair of divine sneakers** in a thrift store. - The camera **pans to a winged logo** on a **new Nike collab**. - The gods **get a DM from an unknown number**: *"We need to talk."* ### **F. Make the Humor More Specific & Less "Generic Funny"** - **Current:** The humor comes from **gods being bad at modern life** (e.g., Zeus struggles with a smartphone). - **Human Twist:** - What if the humor comes from **obsessive, niche details**? - Hermes **has a spreadsheet tracking every sneaker drop**. - Athena **wrote a 50-page manifesto on why the Air Force 1 is the perfect shoe**. - Ares **keeps trying to start a sneaker fight club**. - What if the humor comes from **godly pettiness**? - Zeus **refuses to acknowledge Nike’s existence** because "I invented lightning, not swooshes." - Hades **keeps trying to trademark the phrase "Just Do It (In the Underworld)."** - Aphrodite **gets into a Twitter feud with a sneakerhead over who has better taste**. - What if the humor comes from **modern frustrations clashing with divinity**? - Hermes **gets stuck in traffic** and **starts teleporting cars out of his way**. - Dionysus **tries to get into a sneaker convention but gets carded**. - Poseidon **keeps getting his Yeezys wet** and **blames Jace**. --- ## **5. Key Takeaways for a More Human Story** To make *Gods Wore Sneakers* feel **less like an LLM’s polished fantasy and more like a human’s weird, messy, hilarious story**, we should: ### **A. Embrace the Absurdity (Without Explaining It)** - **Let the weirdness breathe.** If a god **wears sneakers with actual wings**, don’t **over-explain it**—just **let it be weird**. - **Avoid "cool for the sake of cool."** The sneakers should **feel like real shoes**—scuffed, smelly, impractical—**not like magical artifacts**. ### **B. Make the Characters Flawed & Funny (Not Just Competent or Noble)** - **Jace should be *bad* at this.** He’s **not a hero**—he’s a **guy who got in over his head**. - **The gods should be *embarrassing*.** They’re **not wise mentors**—they’re **washed-up deities who don’t get modern life**. - **The Fade should be *wrong*.** His plan should be **dumb, but he’s too stubborn to admit it**. ### **C. Let the Conflict Be Messy (Not a Clean "Good vs. Evil")** - **The gods don’t need to be "saved."** Maybe they **like being forgotten**. - **The sneakers don’t need to be "returned."** Maybe they **want to be erased**. - **The ending doesn’t need to be happy.** Maybe **nothing changes**—or maybe **everything gets worse**. ### **D. Use Humor That’s Specific (Not Just "Gods in Modern Life")** - **Lean into niche obsessions.** Sneakerhead culture, **corporate jargon, gym bro energy**—these are **funny because they’re real**. - **Let the gods be petty.** They’re **not above Twitter fights or bad Yelp reviews**. - **Make the jokes *awkward*.** Gods **shouldn’t sound cool**—they should **sound like they’re trying too hard**. ### **E. Leave Some Things Unresolved (Because Life Is Messy)** - **Not every question needs an answer.** What happens if you **wear two pairs of divine sneakers at once?** Who knows! **Don’t explain it.** - **The ending should feel *real*, not *neat*.** Maybe **Jace gets what he wants—but it’s not what he expected**. - **Let the reader wonder.** Is Jace **hallucinating**? Are the shoes **cursed or just weird**? **Don’t spell it out.** --- ## **Final Thought: What Would a Human Writer Do Differently?** A human writer would **take more risks**. They’d: - **Let the protagonist fail** (instead of always making the "right" choice). - **Make the gods *unlikable*** (instead of noble or tragic). - **Leave the ending *open*** (instead of wrapping everything up). - **Use humor that’s *specific and weird*** (instead of broad and safe). - **Embrace the *awkwardness*** (instead of sanding it down). Most importantly, a human writer would **write like they’re telling this story to a friend at a bar**—not like they’re trying to impress a publisher. **Next steps?** - **Pick 2-3 of these humanizing ideas** and **weave them into the chapter plan**. - **Focus on making Jace more flawed, the gods more petty, and the conflict messier**. - **Cut any "neat" resolutions** that feel too LLM-polished. Would you like to **revise the chapter plan** with these ideas in mind, or **brainstorm specific scenes** that lean into the messier, more human approach?
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# **Final Plan: *Gods Wore Sneakers*** *(A humanlike, messy, and compelling 8-chapter urban fantasy-comedy)* --- ## **# Intention** ### **Core Vision** *Gods Wore Sneakers* is a **fast, funny, and slightly tragic** urban fantasy about **forgotten gods clinging to relevance in a world that no longer worships them**—and the **cynical sneaker reseller who accidentally becomes their last hope (or their biggest mistake)**. The story **embraces the absurdity of gods in sneakers** while grounding it in **real human flaws, petty conflicts, and the mundane struggles of modern life**. ### **What This Story Is** ✅ **A subversion of mythology** – The gods aren’t noble or wise; they’re **washed-up, petty, and desperate**, using sneakers as a last-ditch effort to stay relevant. ✅ **A character-driven comedy** – The humor comes from **gods being bad at modern life**, not just "gods in modern settings." ✅ **A messy, unresolved conflict** – The ending isn’t neat. The gods don’t get a happy ending. Jace doesn’t become a hero. ✅ **A sneakerhead’s fever dream** – The sneakers aren’t just magical; they’re **weird, specific, and sometimes broken**, like real rare kicks. ✅ **A story about faith and consumerism** – What happens when **worship is replaced by hype**? When **gods become brands**? ### **What This Story Is *Not*** ❌ **A "chosen one" narrative** – Jace isn’t special. He’s just a guy who **got in over his head**. ❌ **A clean, polished fantasy** – The worldbuilding is **dripped in naturally**, not explained in info-dumps. ❌ **A hero’s journey** – Jace **doesn’t grow into a better person**. He just **stumbles through the mess he made**. ❌ **A villain with a tragic backstory** – The Fade isn’t misunderstood; he’s **a bitter ex-god with a dumb plan**. ❌ **A story where everything is resolved** – The gods don’t get their power back. The sneakers don’t get "fixed." Life goes on. ### **Stylistic Choices** 🎯 **Voice:** **Snappy, observational, and slightly cynical**—like a **sneakerhead YouTuber telling a wild story**. The narration is **close to Jace’s perspective**, with **dry humor and modern slang**. 🎯 **Dialogue:** **Gods sound like they’re trying too hard to be cool** (e.g., Zeus saying *"Bet"* unironically). **Jace sounds like a real 20-something**—sarcastic, a little lost, but not stupid. 🎯 **Pacing:** **Fast and episodic**—each chapter is **a self-contained scene** with its own mini-conflict, ending on a **hook or twist**. 🎯 **Humor:** **Specific, awkward, and sometimes dark**—not just "gods in modern life," but **gods failing at modern life**. 🎯 **Ending:** **Bittersweet and open-ended**—no neat resolution, just **the next weird thing happening**. ### **Key Themes** 🔹 **Faith vs. Hype** – What happens when **worship becomes consumerism**? When **gods become brands**? 🔹 **The Cost of Irrelevance** – The gods aren’t just weak; they’re **embarrassing**. They’ve **lost their purpose**. 🔹 **Addiction to Power** – Jace **keeps wearing the shoes even though they’re hurting him**—because **he likes the high**. 🔹 **Mythology as a Cycle** – The gods **don’t get a happy ending**. They just **keep existing, forgotten but not gone**. --- ## **# Chapter Planning** ### **Structural Notes** - **Each chapter is ~1,000 words** – **tight, punchy, and focused on one key scene**. - **No info-dumps** – The world is **revealed through action, dialogue, and Jace’s confusion**. - **No neat resolutions** – Each chapter **ends on a hook, a twist, or a new problem**. - **Jace is not a hero** – He’s **selfish, scared, and bad at this**. The gods are **not his mentors**. --- ### **Chapter 1: The Thrift Store Score** **Goal:** Introduce Jace, the sneakers, and the first hint of weirdness. - **Opening:** Jace, a **struggling sneaker reseller**, flips through a thrift store’s shoe rack. He’s **broke, cynical, and desperate**—his last resale fell through, and his mom keeps asking when he’ll get a "real job." - **The Find:** He spots a **pristine pair of vintage Nikes** with **weird wing-like logos** (Hermes’ sandals, reimagined). The store owner, an **old man with unsettlingly sharp eyes**, sells them to him for **$20**. - **First Sign of Power:** On his way home, Jace is **mugged by a group of teens**. In a panic, he **runs faster than he ever has**, leaving them in the dust. He chalks it up to adrenaline. - **The Glitch:** He gets home and **notices the shoes are glowing faintly** in the dark. Before he can investigate, his phone buzzes—**a sneaker app notification: "RARE NIKE X HERMES COLLAB DETECTED NEAR YOU."** - **The Hook:** He dismisses it as a glitch, but when he checks the app again, **everyone in his city is suddenly searching for the same shoes**. - **Ending:** He lists them on eBay for **$10,000**. Within an hour, the bid is at **$5,000**. His hands start shaking. **The shoes are warm.** --- ### **Chapter 2: The Delivery Driver** **Goal:** Introduce Hermes, establish the gods’ desperation, and show Jace’s first real conflict. - **The DM:** Jace gets a **mysterious DM**: *"Those aren’t for sale. Meet me at the old subway station. Alone."* - **The Encounter:** Jace goes to the station, where he meets **a fast-talking delivery driver** (Hermes in disguise). Hermes **recognizes the shoes immediately** and demands them back. - **The Chase:** Jace refuses, and Hermes **loses his temper**, revealing his **supernatural speed**. Jace barely escapes, but not before Hermes **slips a business card into his pocket**: *"Call me when you realize what you’re holding."* - **The Cost:** Jace gets home and **notices his reflection is flickering**—for a second, he sees **a winged figure in the mirror**. - **The Hook:** His phone buzzes again—this time, **a news alert: "LOCAL MAN REPORTED MISSING AFTER BUYING 'CURSED' SNEAKERS."** The article includes a blurry photo of **the old man from the thrift store**. - **Ending:** Jace **blocks Hermes’ number** and **keeps the shoes on**. --- ### **Chapter 3: The Sneaker Convention Chaos** **Goal:** Show the gods’ desperation, introduce The Fade, and escalate the conflict. - **The Hype:** Jace decides to **sell the shoes at a local sneaker convention**, where he can get the best price. The convention is **packed with collectors, resellers, and influencers**—all obsessed with rare kicks. - **The Gods Arrive:** Unbeknownst to Jace, **the convention is a gathering place for gods in disguise**: - **Athena** (a corporate strategist) is **hacking the bidding system**. - **Ares** (a gym bro) is **starting fights in line**. - **Dionysus** (a party promoter) is **spiking the punch**. - **The Auction:** Jace puts the shoes up for auction, and the **bidding war turns violent**. Ares **punches a bidder**, Dionysus **accidentally turns the crowd into a mosh pit**, and Athena **wins the bid**—but Jace **snatches the shoes back and runs**. - **The Fade Appears:** As Jace flees, **The Fade**—a **tall, gaunt figure in a tattered hoodie**—**erases a pair of sneakers right in front of him**, leaving only a **scorch mark on the floor**. - **The Hook:** Hermes **appears beside him in a car**. *"Get in. We need to talk."* - **Ending:** Jace **hesitates**—but then **The Fade’s voice echoes**: *"You’re running out of time, little thief."* --- ### **Chapter 4: The Truth (But Not Really)** **Goal:** Hermes explains *just enough* to freak Jace out—but not enough to make him comply. - **The Ride:** Hermes takes Jace to an **abandoned church** (now a sneaker storage unit) and **explains the truth**: - The shoes are **Hermes’ winged sandals**, reimagined as sneakers. They grant **supernatural speed**, but **the longer a mortal wears them, the more they risk becoming a god**. - The Fade is **erasing divine relics** to force the gods back into obscurity. If he destroys the shoes, **Hermes will lose his power permanently**. - **Jace’s Refusal:** Jace **doesn’t believe him** at first, but then Hermes **shows him a vision**—Jace sees **Hermes’ memories: the fall of Olympus, the gods scattering, the sneakers being lost**. - **The Offer:** Hermes asks Jace to **return the shoes**, but Jace **refuses**—he needs the money. Hermes warns him: *"The shoes will change you. And not in a good way."* - **The Hook:** As Jace leaves, **The Fade appears in the rearview mirror**. *"You’re not the first mortal to wear those. You’re just the first one who didn’t *scream*."* - **Ending:** Jace **keeps the shoes on**—but now **he’s hearing whispers**. --- ### **Chapter 5: The Addiction** **Goal:** Show Jace’s descent into power—and his refusal to stop. - **The Voices:** Jace starts **hearing whispers** in his head—**Hermes’ voice, urging him to run faster, to never stop moving**. He **ignores them at first**, but the whispers grow louder. - **The Power Trip:** He **uses the shoes to win a street race**, earning **$5,000 in cash**. For the first time in months, he feels **invincible**. - **The Cost:** After the race, he **collapses**. When he looks in the mirror, **his eyes are glowing gold**. His reflection **winks at him**. - **The Warning:** Hermes tracks him down again. *"You’re changing. The shoes are bonding to you. If you keep wearing them, you’ll become one of us."* - **The Choice:** Jace **doesn’t care**—he’s **too addicted to the power**. But then he sees **a news report: The Fade has erased another divine item, and a god has vanished**. - **The Hook:** Jace realizes **he’s not just risking his humanity—he’s risking the gods’ existence**. - **Ending:** He **keeps wearing the shoes**. --- ### **Chapter 6: The Gods’ Last Stand (That Isn’t Really a Stand)** **Goal:** Show the gods’ desperation—and Jace’s betrayal. - **The Gathering:** The gods **convene in an abandoned sneaker warehouse** (their new "Olympus"). They’re **weak, divided, and desperate**: - **Zeus** (a retired basketball star) wants to **storm The Fade’s hideout**. - **Athena** wants to **negotiate**. - **Ares** just wants to **fight something**. - **The Plan:** Hermes suggests **using Jace as bait**—if they can get the shoes back, they can **restore their power**. The gods **agree, reluctantly**. - **The Betrayal:** Jace **overhears their plan** and **realizes they don’t care about him**—they just want the shoes. He **steals a pair of Zeus’ sneakers** (which grant **storm manipulation**) and **escapes**. - **The Fade’s Move:** The Fade **appears before Jace** and offers him a deal: *"Give me the shoes, and I’ll let you keep your humanity."* - **The Hook:** Jace **hesitates**—but then he **sees his reflection again**, and this time, **it smiles back at him**. - **Ending:** He **keeps the shoes**. --- ### **Chapter 7: The Final Race (That Isn’t Really Final)** **Goal:** The climax—Jace’s last stand, the gods’ failure, and The Fade’s victory. - **The Chase:** The gods **realize Jace has betrayed them** and **give chase**. Hermes is **furious**, but Athena **understands**—Jace is **scared, not evil**. - **The Showdown:** Jace **uses Zeus’ sneakers to summon a storm**, but **The Fade erases them mid-air**, leaving him **powerless**. The gods **corner him**. - **The Revelation:** The Fade **reveals his true plan**—he’s not trying to destroy the gods, he’s trying to **force them to remember what it means to be divine**. *"You’ve forgotten your purpose. You’ve become *hypebeasts*."* - **Jace’s Choice:** Jace realizes **The Fade is right**—the gods **have lost their way**. But he also knows **erasing the shoes won’t fix anything**. - **The Hook:** He **makes a decision**—one that will **change everything**. - **Ending:** He **returns the shoes to Hermes**—but **not before using them one last time**. --- ### **Chapter 8: The New Pantheon (That Isn’t Really New)** **Goal:** The bittersweet, open-ended conclusion. - **The Sacrifice:** Jace **returns the shoes to Hermes**, but **not before using them one last time**—he **runs so fast he phases out of reality**, leaving behind **a single, glowing sneaker**. - **The Aftermath:** - The gods **regain some power**, but **not all of it**. They’re **still weak, still forgotten**. - The Fade **disappears**, his mission complete—but **nothing really changes**. - Jace **wakes up in his apartment**, unsure if it was all a dream—until he sees **a single winged sneaker on his shelf**. - **The New Era:** The gods **return to the world**, but this time, they **don’t hide**. Athena **opens a sneaker empire**, Hermes **starts a delivery app**, and Zeus **hosts a basketball tournament**. - **The Twist:** In the final scene, **Jace gets a DM from an unknown number**: *"Nice shoes. Where’d you get them?"* The camera pans to **a pair of scuffed, winged sneakers** in a thrift store window. - **Ending:** Jace **smiles**. *"Some things are worth more than money."* --- ## **Final Notes** ✅ **This plan avoids LLM pitfalls** by: - **Making Jace flawed, not heroic**. - **Letting the gods be petty, not wise**. - **Keeping the ending open-ended, not neat**. - **Using humor that’s specific, not generic**. - **Leaving some things unresolved**. ✅ **It serves the original prompt** by: - **Making the sneakers central to the conflict**. - **Exploring the absurdity of gods in modern life**. - **Keeping the tone fast, funny, and slightly tragic**. **Next steps?** - **Write the first chapter** and **see how the voice feels**. - **Adjust pacing** if any chapter feels too slow or too rushed. - **Lean into the weirdness**—the more specific and awkward, the better. Would you like to **refine any chapter further** or **brainstorm specific scenes**?
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
Here’s the deep dive into each main character, grounded in specificity, flaws, and human quirks—designed to avoid LLM tropes (over-explained backstories, noble motives, "cool" dialogue) and instead feel like real, messy individuals in this world. --- # **Jace Morales** ### **Background** - **Age:** 22, but looks 19 when he’s tired (which is always). - **Occupation:** "Sneaker reseller" is a generous term. He’s a **failed eBay flipper** who mostly loses money on fakes, scams, and his own bad decisions. His mom calls it "a phase." His ex called it "a pyramid scheme." - **Upbringing:** Grew up in a **working-class Latino household** in a gentrifying neighborhood. His dad was a mechanic who **hated "wasteful" spending**—Jace’s sneaker obsession started as a rebellion. Now it’s just a habit he can’t quit. - **Education:** Dropped out of community college after one semester of business classes. **Learned more about sneakers from YouTube than he ever did in school.** - **Key Life Events:** - **Got scammed** on his first big resale (bought a "rare" pair of Yeezys that turned out to be fakes). - **Dated a girl who worked at Foot Locker**—she dumped him after he **tried to sell her employee discount shoes**. - **Lives in his childhood bedroom**, which is now a **sneaker storage unit** (his mom threatens to donate his collection if he doesn’t pay rent). - **Current Situation:** **Broke, in debt, and desperate.** His last "big score" fell through when a buyer ghosted him after he shipped the shoes. Now he’s **one bad month away from moving back in with his abuela.** ### **Personality & Idiosyncrasies** - **Cynical but not jaded.** He **rolls his eyes at hypebeasts** but still **gets excited when he finds a good deal.** - **Addicted to the hustle.** He **knows he’s bad at reselling**, but he **can’t stop chasing the next big score.** - **Self-sabotaging.** He **talks himself out of good opportunities** because he’s convinced he’ll mess them up. - **Loyal to a fault**—but only to people who **don’t ask for much.** He’d **give his last dollar to a friend**, but he’d **ghost them if they asked for two.** - **Obsessive about details.** He **knows the exact release date, colorway, and retail price of every major sneaker drop in the last five years.** - **Bad at lying.** He **tries to play it cool** but **always gives himself away** (e.g., sweating when he says he "doesn’t care" about a rare pair). - **Hates authority.** Not in a **rebellious way**—just in a **petty, "I don’t wanna deal with this" way.** He **ignores DMs from gods** the same way he ignores **emails from his bank.** **Trivial but Telling Quirks:** - **Always wears socks with slides** (his ex made fun of him for it, but he doesn’t care). - **Keeps a "sneaker graveyard"** in his closet—**deadstock shoes he’ll never sell because they’re "too special."** - **Hates the smell of new shoes.** Prefers **worn-in, broken-in kicks.** - **Has a fake laugh** he uses when buyers lowball him. It’s **high-pitched and unconvincing.** - **Talks to his shoes** when he’s alone. *"Come on, man, just one more sale."* ### **Physicality** - **Appearance:** - **5’7", skinny but not in a "fit" way**—more like he **forgot to eat for three days.** - **Dark curly hair, always slightly messy** (he cuts it himself in the bathroom mirror). - **Dark circles under his eyes** (from staying up late watching sneaker unboxings). - **Wears the same three outfits** (jeans, a graphic tee, and a hoodie—**all from thrift stores**). - **Always has a sneaker box under his arm** (even when he’s not reselling). - **How He Carries Himself:** - **Slouches when he walks** (like he’s trying to take up less space). - **Fidgets constantly**—**taps his fingers, bounces his leg, adjusts his hat.** - **Avoids eye contact** unless he’s **trying to sell something.** - **Smells like sneaker cleaner and old coffee.** - **Expressions & Tics:** - **Raises one eyebrow when he’s skeptical** (which is often). - **Bites his lip when he’s lying.** - **Talks with his hands** when he’s excited (which is rare). - **Always has one earbud in** (even when he’s not listening to music). ### **Motives, Allegiances & Relationships** - **What He Wants:** - **Short-term:** **$10,000 to pay off his debt and move out of his mom’s house.** - **Long-term:** **To prove he’s not a failure.** (He won’t admit this, even to himself.) - **Secretly:** **To feel like he’s part of something bigger.** (Hence the sneaker obsession—**it’s the closest thing he has to a community.**) - **What He Fears:** - **Ending up like his dad**—**stuck in a job he hates, bitter about the past.** - **Being forgotten.** (He **hates when people don’t recognize rare shoes**—it’s like they’re **erasing his knowledge.**) - **The shoes changing him.** (But he **keeps wearing them anyway.**) - **Allies (Reluctant or Otherwise):** - **Hermes** – **Annoying but useful.** Jace **doesn’t trust him**, but he’s the only one who **actually explains things.** - **His mom** – **Wants him to "get a real job."** He **avoids her calls.** - **His ex, Maria** – **Works at Foot Locker.** She **still texts him memes**, but he **never replies.** - **The sneakerhead community** – **A mix of friends and rivals.** He **knows everyone’s username but no one’s real name.** - **Enemies (Or People He’s Pissed Off):** - **The Fade** – **Creepy and persistent.** Jace **doesn’t understand his deal**, but he **hates being told what to do.** - **Ares** – **A meathead who keeps trying to fight him.** - **His bank** – **Won’t stop calling about his overdraft.** - **Himself** – **He’s his own worst enemy.** ### **Flavor Dialogue / Internal Monologue** **Dialogue (to Hermes, when he’s trying to sell the shoes):** *"Look, man, I don’t know what kind of ‘divine relic’ scam you’re running, but I’m not buying. These are just shoes. Expensive shoes, but still. Shoes."* **Internal Monologue (when he first hears the whispers):** *"Okay, that was definitely a voice. Not my voice. A voice-voice. Like, a real one. Shit. Did I finally lose it? Or did I just get a really good deal on some haunted sneakers?"* **Dialogue (to himself, after using the shoes to win a race):** *"Okay, that was… that was not normal. That was *super* not normal. But also, $5,000. So. Worth it?"* **Internal Monologue (when he realizes the gods don’t care about him):** *"Oh, so I’m just bait now? Cool. Cool cool cool. Not like I had anything better to do. Not like I was using these shoes to *not* be a failure."* --- # **Hermes** ### **Background** - **Divine Title:** *Messenger of the Gods, God of Thieves, Travelers, and Sneakerheads.* - **Age:** **~3,000 years old**, but **acts like a 25-year-old who peaked in college.** - **Modern Identity:** **Delivery driver for a gig app** (he **chose this job because it lets him move fast and avoid paperwork**). - **Divine Downfall:** **Olympus fell, and no one told him.** One day, he was **delivering a message to Zeus**, and the next, he was **standing in an empty temple with a "FOR RENT" sign.** - **Current Situation:** **Struggling to keep up with rent** (he **lives in a studio apartment above a sneaker store**). His **divine powers are fading**, but he **refuses to admit it.** - **Key Mythological Moments (That Haunt Him):** - **Stole Apollo’s cattle when he was a baby.** (Apollo **still brings it up at parties.**) - **Invented the lyre.** (He **wishes he’d patented it.**) - **Guided souls to the Underworld.** (Now he **just delivers DoorDash.**) ### **Personality & Idiosyncrasies** - **Fast-talking but not smooth.** He **thinks he’s charming**, but he **comes off as desperate.** - **A hustler, but not a good one.** He **tries to scam mortals** but **always gets scammed worse.** - **Loyal to the gods, but only because he has no one else.** He **doesn’t actually like most of them.** - **Obsessed with modern slang.** He **uses it wrong** (e.g., *"Bet, no cap, slay queen."*). - **A terrible liar.** He **thinks he’s good at it**, but he **always gives himself away** (e.g., **sweating, avoiding eye contact, over-explaining**). - **Addicted to the gig economy.** He **could teleport anywhere**, but he **still takes delivery jobs because he likes the dopamine hit of a five-star rating.** - **Hates being alone.** He **talks to inanimate objects** when he’s bored (e.g., *"Come on, GPS, don’t fail me now."*). **Trivial but Telling Quirks:** - **Always wears mismatched socks** (one winged, one plain). - **Keeps a burner phone for scams** (it’s **always dead**). - **Has a fake mustache in his glove compartment** (he **thinks it makes him look mysterious**). - **Names his delivery bags** (his current one is called **Steve**). - **Hates the smell of ambrosia** (he **misses real food**). ### **Physicality** - **Appearance:** - **5’9", wiry and restless**—like he’s **always about to bolt.** - **Dark, curly hair that’s always slightly greasy** (he **washes it with dish soap**). - **Sharp, angular face**—**looks like a fox who got caught stealing.** - **Wears a delivery uniform** (but **rolls up the sleeves and undoes the top button**). - **Always has a coffee in hand** (even though **he doesn’t like coffee**—he just likes the **ritual of it**). - **How He Carries Himself:** - **Moves like he’s late for something** (even when he’s not). - **Talks with his hands**—**gestures wildly when he’s lying.** - **Always has one foot out the door.** - **Smells like fast food and cheap cologne.** - **Expressions & Tics:** - **Grins when he’s nervous.** - **Taps his fingers when he’s thinking** (like he’s **typing on an invisible keyboard**). - **Avoids direct questions** by **asking another question.** - **Always has a toothpick in his mouth** (even though he **doesn’t smoke**). ### **Motives, Allegiances & Relationships** - **What He Wants:** - **Short-term:** **Get the shoes back from Jace** (so he can **stop fading**). - **Long-term:** **Find a way to restore the gods’ power** (but he **doesn’t have a plan**). - **Secretly:** **Prove he’s still useful.** (He **hates that the other gods see him as a joke.**) - **What He Fears:** - **Being forgotten.** (He **checks his phone constantly**, hoping for a **divine text that never comes**.) - **Becoming mortal.** (He **doesn’t know how to live without powers**.) - **That the gods don’t actually need him.** (They **only call when they need something delivered**.) - **Allies (Sort Of):** - **Jace** – **Annoying but useful.** Hermes **doesn’t like him**, but he’s the **only one who can get the shoes back.** - **Athena** – **The only god who still respects him.** (She **gives him business advice**.) - **His delivery app rating** – **The only thing that makes him feel validated.** - **Enemies (Or People He’s Pissed Off):** - **Zeus** – **Still mad about the cattle thing.** - **Apollo** – **Won’t stop bragging about the lyre.** - **The Fade** – **Creepy and persistent.** Hermes **doesn’t trust him.** - **His GPS** – **It keeps rerouting him.** ### **Flavor Dialogue / Internal Monologue** **Dialogue (to Jace, trying to convince him to return the shoes):** *"Look, man, I get it. You think these are just some rare kicks. But trust me, you do *not* want to know what happens when a mortal wears a god’s shoes for too long. Last guy? Turned into a pigeon. Not even a cool pigeon. A *gross* one."* **Internal Monologue (when he realizes Jace isn’t listening):** *"Ugh. Mortals. Why do I even bother? Oh right, because if I don’t, I’m gonna fade into nothing. Again. Fuck my life."* **Dialogue (to Athena, complaining about Jace):** *"He’s impossible! I told him the shoes are cursed, and he just said, ‘Cool, more hype.’ What is *wrong* with mortals?"* **Internal Monologue (when he’s alone in his apartment):** *"I used to deliver *messages from the gods*. Now I deliver *burritos*. How did it come to this? Oh right, because no one believes in us anymore.
