Ghosts don’t fill out witness statements."* - **Secretly superstitious**: **Knocks on wood**, **avoids cracks in the pavement**, **has a lucky tie** (a **hideous Christmas present from his ex**). - **Hates teenagers**: **Thinks they’re all "mouthy little shits"**—but **respects Mars** because she **doesn’t kiss his arse**. - **Knows more than he lets on**: **Was the first responder when Debs drowned**. **Never solved the case**. **Hasn’t told anyone**. ### **Physicality** - **Appearance**: **Balding, with a **grey moustache** he **trims every Sunday**. **Paunchy**, but **moves like a man who used to be fit**. **Always in a slightly rumpled suit**. - **Clothing**: **Cheap suits**, **scuffed shoes**, **a coffee-stained tie**. **Smells like stale coffee and Old Spice**. - **Body language**: - **Rubs his temples** when he’s stressed. - **Sighs a lot** (like a **deflating balloon**). - **Avoids physical contact** (even handshakes). - **How he interacts with the world**: - **Talks in a monotone**, but **his eyes give him away** (they **narrow when he’s suspicious**, **soften when he’s sad**). - **Always has a **mints in his pocket** (he **quit smoking**, but **still reaches for them**). - **Never sits down in public** (like he’s **always ready to leave**). ### **Motives, Allegiances & Relationships** - **Motives**: - **Short-term**: **Solve the "emoji deaths"** before **someone *actually* gets hurt** (and before his **boss chews him out**). - **Long-term**: **Retire**, **move to Spain**, **never see this town again**. - **Secret motive**: **Find out what *really* happened to Debs**—but he’s **too scared to dig too deep**. - **Allegiances**: - **The law** (but he **bends the rules** when it suits him). - **Himself** (he **doesn’t trust anyone**, not even his **partner**). - **Mars** (he **doesn’t want to admit it**, but he **sees himself in her**). - **Relationships**: - **Mars**: **Mutual eye-rolling**. He **thinks she’s a pain**; she **thinks he’s a has-been**. But he **gives her more leeway than other kids**. - **Lola**: **Finds her exhausting**, but **secretly impressed by her research skills**. - **Debs (ghost)**: **Doesn’t believe in ghosts**—but he **still has her case file in his desk**. ### **Flavour Dialogue / Internal Monologue** - **Dialogue**: - (To Mars) *"I’ve got three missing cats, a bloke who thinks his neighbour’s a vampire, and *you*. My day is *complete*."* - (To Lola, after she suggests the emojis are a government experiment) *"Right. And I suppose the Queen’s a lizard person?"* - **Internal monologue**: - *"I should’ve left this town years ago. But where the hell would I go?"* - *"That kid [Mars] reminds me of me at her age. And that’s *terrifying*."* --- # **Debs (The Ghost of Debra Holloway)** ### **Background & Personality** - **Age when she died**: 17. **Drowned off the pier in 1987**, after a **party got out of hand**. **No one knows if it was an accident or suicide**—but **she was drunk, and the railing was loose**. - **Personality (when alive)**: - **Quiet, but not shy**: **Didn’t talk much**, but **had a sharp wit** when she did. Example: When a teacher told her to "speak up," she said, *"I’d rather not. You won’t like what I have to say."* - **Loved the sea**: **Would skip school to sit on the pier and draw**. **Wanted to be a marine biologist**. - **Had a crush on a boy who ignored her**: **Wrote his name in her diary**, **never told him**. - **Felt invisible**: **No one noticed when she was sad**. **No one noticed when she was gone**. - **Personality (as a ghost)**: - **Confused, angry, lonely**: **Doesn’t understand she’s dead**. **Thinks she’s still alive**, just **stuck in some kind of limbo**. - **Tries to communicate, but fails**: **Sends emojis because she thinks that’s how people talk now**. **Doesn’t realise they’re being misinterpreted**. - **Not evil, but not "nice" either**: **Doesn’t *want* to hurt people**, but **doesn’t care if they get scared**. - **Haunts the places she loved**: **The pier, the chip shop (where she worked part-time), the library (where she’d hide during lunch)**. ### **Physicality** - **Appearance (as a ghost)**: - **Looks like she did when she died**: **Wet hair, pale skin, a **red scarf** (the one she wore the night she drowned) **draped over her shoulders**. - **Not see-through, but *flickering***: Like a **badly tuned TV**. **Sometimes she’s solid, sometimes she’s not**. - **Smells like seaweed and rain**. - **Body language**: - **Stands too close to people**, like she’s **trying to get their attention**. - **Reaches out**, but **her hand passes through them**. - **Never blinks**. - **How she interacts with the world**: - **Whispers** (but **no one hears her**). - **Moves objects** (but **only when no one’s looking**). - **Texts people** (but **her messages don’t always send**). ### **Motives, Allegiances & Relationships** - **Motives**: - **Short-term**: **Get someone to *notice* her**. - **Long-term**: **Figure out why she’s still here**. - **Secret motive**: **She doesn’t want to move on**—she’s **afraid of being forgotten**. - **Allegiances**: - **Herself** (but she **doesn’t know who that is anymore**). - **Mars** (she **senses Mars is different**—**less scared, more curious**). - **Relationships**: - **Mars**: **Fascinated by her**. **Tries to warn her**, but **Mars doesn’t understand**. - **Lola**: **Finds her annoying** (she **keeps trying to "solve" the mystery**). - **DI Farley**: **Doesn’t remember him** (but he **remembers her**). ### **Flavour Dialogue / Internal Monologue** - **Dialogue (via text)**: - *"You’re next."* - *"I just wanted someone to *see* me."* - **Internal monologue (if she had one)**: - *"Why won’t anyone *listen* to me?"* - *"I don’t want to be here anymore. But I don’t want to *leave* either."* --- # **Mr. Puddlefoot** ### **Background & Personality** - **Age**: **No one knows**. **Old enough to remember when the pier had a roller disco**. - **Background**: **Former fisherman**, now the town’s **unofficial historian**. **Lives in a caravan by the beach** (it **smells like damp and old books**). - **Personality**: - **Eccentric, but not crazy**: **Talks in riddles**, but **knows more than he lets on**. - **Loves the sea**: **Calls it "the old girl"** and **gets emotional when it storms**. - **Hates tourists**: **Thinks they’re "ruining the town"** (but he’ll **sell them a "lucky shell" for £5**). - **Secretly lonely**: **Hasn’t had a real conversation in years**. ### **Physicality** - **Appearance**: **Tall and gaunt**, with **wild white hair** and **a beard that hasn’t been trimmed since 1998**. **Wears a **fisherman’s sweater** (even in summer) and **wellies** (even indoors). - **Clothing**: **Always has a **pipe in his mouth** (he **doesn’t smoke it**, just chews on it). - **Body language**: - **Leans in too close** when he talks. - **Mumbles**, but **if you listen, he makes sense**. - **Always fiddling with something** (a **piece of rope, a shell, a coin**). ### **Motives, Allegiances & Relationships** - **Motives**: - **Short-term**: **Get someone to listen to him**. - **Long-term**: **Die knowing he told the truth**. - **Allegiances**: - **The sea** (he **believes it’s alive**). - **Debs** (he **knew her**, but **won’t say how**). - **Relationships**: - **Mars**: **Sees her as a "kindred spirit"** (she **doesn’t realise it yet**). - **Lola**: **Finds her annoying**, but **respects her research**. - **DI Farley**: **Mutual eye-rolling**. ### **Flavour Dialogue / Internal Monologue** - **Dialogue**: - *"The sea don’t forget, girl. And neither do I."* - *"You think you’re the first to ask about the drowned girl? You won’t be the last."* - **Internal monologue**: - *"I should’ve said something back then. But what’s the point now?"* --- ### **Final Notes** - **These characters are *flawed, messy, and real***. They **don’t exist to serve the plot**—they **drive it**. - **Their voices are *distinct***. You should be able to **tell who’s talking without dialogue tags**. - **They *change*, but not in a neat way**. Mars **doesn’t "solve" the mystery**—she **just gets more confused**. Lola **doesn’t "learn her lesson"**—she **doubles down**. DI Farley **doesn’t "find closure"**—he **just gets more tired**. Would you like to **refine any character further**? Or should we **dive into writing a chapter**?

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 1: The Text** The Golden Fry smelled like regret and old oil. Mars leaned against the counter, watching the last of the day’s tourists shuffle out with their greasy parcels of chips, their laughter already fading into the damp evening air. The clock above the fryer read 11:47 PM. Thirteen minutes until she could lock up, go home, and pretend this day had never happened. Her phone buzzed in her pocket. She ignored it. Probably Lola, sending another meme about the apocalypse or whatever conspiracy theory she was obsessed with this week. The fryer hissed. A drop of water from the ceiling landed on the counter with a *plink*. Mars wiped it away with her sleeve, leaving a smear of vinegar and salt. Another buzz. Then another. She sighed, pulled out her phone, and nearly dropped it. **Unknown number:** 🩸🩸🩸 Mars stared at the screen. Her thumb hovered over the keyboard. Then, because she was an idiot, she typed: *Lols if this is u i swear to god* The message sat there, delivered but unread. No typing bubbles. No reply. She waited. Ten seconds. Twenty. The fryer gurgled. *Weird.* She Googled *"three blood emojis meaning"* and got a Reddit thread about period tracking, a Wikipedia page for the Unicode Consortium, and a Tumblr post from 2016 about a creepypasta involving a cursed text chain. Nothing useful. Her phone buzzed again. **Unknown number:** *Debs* Mars’ stomach twisted. She didn’t know any Debs. At least, she didn’t *think* she did. She typed back: *Who is this?* No reply. The freezer behind her hummed, then fell silent. A second later, a whisper slithered out from behind the metal door. *"Mars."* She spun around. The freezer was shut. The kitchen was empty. Her pulse hammered in her throat. She told herself it was the fryer. Or the wind. Or her own brain, finally snapping after too many shifts in this hellhole. She grabbed her bag, flicked off the lights, and locked up. The sea breeze hit her as she stepped outside, carrying the scent of salt and diesel. The pier loomed in the distance, its skeletal frame jutting into the black water like broken teeth. Her phone buzzed again. She didn’t look at it until she was home, curled under her duvet with the curtains drawn. The screen glowed in the dark. **Unknown number:** *You’re next.* She blocked the number. Then she unblocked it. Then she turned her phone off and went to sleep. The next morning, her notifications were full of the same three emojis, sent at 12:03 AM. Like clockwork.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This opening chapter establishes a strong foundation for the darkly comic British YA story. The writing demonstrates solid technical competence and successfully introduces the central mystery while establishing Mars as a compelling protagonist. The characterization of Mars feels authentic and well-developed. Her voice comes through clearly - sarcastic, tired, defensive - without falling into the trap of being overly quippy. Lines like "The Golden Fry smelled like regret and old oil" and her internal commentary show personality without forced cleverness. The detail about her wiping away water "with her sleeve, leaving a smear of vinegar and salt" effectively conveys both the grimy setting and her resigned acceptance of it. The supernatural elements are introduced with appropriate restraint. The whisper from the freezer is genuinely unsettling without being overwrought, and the escalating text messages create mounting tension. The model wisely avoids over-explaining the mystery, letting it unfold naturally. The setting feels lived-in and authentic. The chip shop environment is rendered with specific, sensory details that avoid cliché. The description of tourists "shuffling out with their greasy parcels" and the pier as "skeletal frame jutting into the black water like broken teeth" creates atmosphere without purple prose. However, there are some weaknesses. The pacing feels slightly rushed in places - the transition from the first emoji text to "Debs" to "You're next" happens quite quickly, potentially diminishing the impact of each revelation. The ending sequence with Mars blocking/unblocking the number and the final revelation about the recurring notifications feels somewhat mechanical. The dialogue, while limited, works well. Mars's text response "Lols if this is u i swear to god" feels genuinely teenage without being performatively so. The internal monologue maintains consistency with her established voice. The chapter adheres closely to the planned structure and successfully establishes the key elements: Mars's character, the mysterious texts, the first supernatural encounter, and the hook for future chapters. It faithfully serves the writing prompt by centering the midnight emoji text as the inciting incident. Some minor issues include occasional awkward phrasing ("Her pulse hammered in her throat") and the metaphor about the pier, while evocative, borders on slightly overwrought for the otherwise grounded tone. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 2: The First Reaction** Mars woke up to the sound of her mum banging on her bedroom door. “Marnie! You’re gonna be late!” She groaned, rolled over, and immediately regretted it when her phone dug into her ribs. She pulled it out. Seven missed calls from Lola. A dozen messages in the group chat. *BLOOD CULT OF 2024* She rubbed her eyes and opened it. **Lola:** OMG DID U SEE THE TEXT **Lola:** MARS U THERE **Lola:** IT’S A SIGN **Lola:** WE’RE ALL GONNA DIE **Josh (Year 10):** my cousin got the same text and now he’s missing **Tasha (Head Bitch of Year 11):** this isnt funny lola **Lola:** IT’S NOT A JOKE **Lola:** IT’S A *WARNING* **Danny (Lola’s Stoner Brother):** i sacrificed a sausage roll to the blood gods Mars groaned and typed: *Lols if this is about the emojis it’s not a cult it’s just some wanker* **Lola:** IT’S NOT A WANKER **Lola:** IT’S *THE SUPERNATURAL* **Josh:** my cousin is *definitely* missing **Mars:** ur cousin is at football **Josh:** oh **Josh:** wait no he’s back **Josh:** he was just in the bog **Tasha:** this is *exactly* what they want u to think **Danny:** who’s they **Tasha:** *THEM* A pause. Then— **Lola:** WE SHOULD ALL WEAR RED TOMORROW TO PROTECT OURSELVES Mars threw her phone onto the bed and buried her face in her pillow. Her mum shouted something from the kitchen about burnt toast. She ignored her. --- The Golden Fry was dead at lunchtime, which meant Mars had nothing to do but wipe down the same sticky tables over and over. Lola burst in at 1:17 PM, her face flushed, her bleached hair sticking up in clumps like she’d been electrocuted. “Mars,” she gasped, slamming her hands on the counter. “We have to talk.” “No.” “Yes.” “Lola, if this is about the—” “It’s *not* a prank.” Lola’s eyes were wide, her pupils huge. “I looked it up. Three drops of blood is a *sign*. Like, in the Bible. Or, like, in *occult symbolism*.” Mars stared at her. “You Googled *occult symbolism*?” “Yes! And also, my nan says—” “Your nan also thinks the government puts microchips in sausages.” “She’s *right* about some things!” Lola leaned in. “Mars, what if it’s *real*?” Mars exhaled through her nose. “It’s not.” “But what if it is?” “It’s not.” “But—” “Lola.” Lola deflated. “Fine. But if I die tonight, I’m haunting *you*.” Mars tossed her a bag of scraps. “Here. Feed the seagulls. Maybe they’ll protect you.” Lola caught the bag and scowled. “You’re the worst.” --- Mars was elbow-deep in the fryer when the first scream went up. It came from the pier. She didn’t react at first—people screamed on the pier all the time. Kids dared each other to jump the railing, drunk tourists slipped on the wet boards, seagulls dive-bombed old ladies for their chips. But then she heard the shouting. “*Call an ambulance!*” “*He’s not breathing!*” “*Someone help!*” Mars wiped her hands on her apron and stepped outside. A small crowd had gathered at the end of the pier, their voices sharp with panic. She squinted. Someone was on the ground. Someone old. Someone familiar. Old Man Higgins. He was sprawled on his back, one leg bent at a weird angle, his face pale. A woman in a neon windbreaker was pressing her hands to his chest. Another man was on the phone, his voice high and frantic. “*Yeah, the pier! He just—he just fell!*” Mars’ stomach lurched. Lola appeared at her side, breathless. “Oh my god. Oh my god.” “What happened?” “I don’t know! I was walking past and—” Lola’s hands were shaking. “Mars, what if it’s *them*?” Mars didn’t answer. She was too busy staring at the wet patch on the pier, right where Higgins had fallen. A dark, glistening smear. Like blood. But it wasn’t blood. It was just water. Wasn’t it? --- The group chat exploded. **Lola:** THE FIRST BLOOD DROP HAS BEEN SPILLED **Josh:** wait what **Tasha:** WHO DIED **Danny:** no one died **Danny:** yet **Lola:** IT’S A *SIGN* **Mars:** it was an accident **Lola:** WAS IT THO **Tasha:** this isnt funny anymore **Josh:** my cousin says its a *gang initiation* **Danny:** what gang **Josh:** idk the *blood gang* Mars locked her phone and shoved it in her pocket. Lola was still talking, her words tumbling over each other. “—and what if it’s not just Higgins? What if it’s, like, a *pattern*? Three drops, three deaths—” “Lola.” “—and what if we’re next?” “Lola.” “What?” Mars looked at her. “It’s a coincidence.” Lola’s face fell. “You don’t *know* that.” No. She didn’t. She pulled out her phone and typed: *Who is this?* She stared at the screen, waiting. Three dots appeared. Then— **Debs:** *You’re next.* Mars’ breath hitched. Lola leaned over her shoulder. “What? What is it?” Mars locked her phone. “Nothing.” Lola’s eyes narrowed. “You’re lying.” “No, I’m not.” “Yes, you are.” “Lola—” “Mars.” Mars exhaled. “Fine. It’s the same number. It just—it said *Debs*.” Lola’s face went very still. “Debs?” “Yeah.” “Like… *Debra Holloway*?” Mars blinked. “Who?” Lola grabbed her arm. “Debs Holloway. She drowned off the pier in, like, the eighties. My nan told me about her. She said—” Lola’s voice dropped to a whisper. “She said Debs *haunts* the pier.” Mars stared at her. Lola’s grip tightened. “Mars. What if it’s *her*?” Mars didn’t answer. Because for the first time since this whole thing started, she was thinking the same thing.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong execution of the darkly comic British YA tone established in the plan. The writing successfully balances supernatural mystery with authentic teenage dialogue and behavior, particularly through the group chat format which feels genuinely contemporary and realistic. The characterization is notably strong. Mars maintains her established voice - sarcastic, defensive, but increasingly unsettled. Her internal conflict between skepticism and growing fear is well-handled, never feeling forced. Lola's dramatic overreaction feels authentic to her character profile, and her research obsession comes through naturally. The group chat participants each have distinct voices despite minimal screen time. The dialogue excels throughout. The group chat messages capture authentic teenage panic and conspiracy-building, with each character maintaining their voice even in brief exchanges. Mars and Lola's face-to-face conversation flows naturally, with realistic interruptions and the kind of circular arguments friends actually have. Lines like "my cousin got the same text and now he's missing" followed by "oh wait no he's back" perfectly capture how teenage panic spirals and deflates. The plot progression follows the chapter plan effectively, escalating from group chat hysteria to the first "accident" with Old Man Higgins. The pacing builds tension appropriately, and the revelation of "Debs" as the sender creates a genuine hook without feeling manipulative. The writing demonstrates strong technical control. Descriptions are economical but vivid - "her bleached hair sticking up in clumps like she'd been electrocuted" efficiently conveys both Lola's appearance and agitated state. The prose avoids purple language while maintaining atmospheric detail. The supernatural elements are handled with appropriate subtlety. The ambiguity around whether Higgins' fall is connected to the texts maintains mystery without becoming frustrating. The final exchange with "Debs" feels genuinely unsettling. Minor weaknesses include some slightly predictable beats in the group chat escalation, and Mars' final moment of doubt could have been developed with slightly more internal complexity. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise well-executed chapter that successfully advances both plot and character development while maintaining the established tone. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 3: The Investigation Begins** Mars didn’t sleep. She lay in bed, staring at the ceiling, her phone clutched in her hand like a grenade with the pin pulled. Every time she closed her eyes, she saw the same thing: Old Man Higgins on the ground, his leg bent at that wrong angle, the wet smear on the pier like a warning. Or a promise. At 3:17 AM, she gave up. She pulled on her hoodie, shoved her feet into her Docs, and crept out of the flat. The streets were empty, the only sound the distant crash of waves against the seawall. The pier loomed ahead, its skeletal frame silhouetted against the dark water. She didn’t want to go near it. She went anyway. --- The library was a squat brick building that smelled like damp paper and regret. Mars had only been inside twice—once for a school trip in Year 7, and once when she’d been desperate for somewhere warm to sit. The librarian, Mrs. Hargreaves, gave her a look when she walked in, like she could smell the chip fat clinging to her clothes. “Closing in twenty minutes,” Mrs. Hargreaves said. “Yeah, yeah.” Mars headed straight for the local history section, where the books were so old they crumbled when you touched them. She pulled out a yellowed volume titled *Seagrave: A Town Through Time* and flipped to the index. *Holloway, Debra—page 142.* The photo was grainy, a black-and-white shot of a girl in a school uniform, her hair pulled back in a messy ponytail. She was smiling, but it didn’t reach her eyes. The caption read: *Debra Holloway, 17, who tragically drowned off Seagrave Pier in 1987. Her body was never recovered.* Mars’s stomach twisted. She turned the page. The article was short. *Local teenager Debra Holloway, 17, is presumed drowned after disappearing from Seagrave Pier late Saturday night. Witnesses reported seeing the girl near the railing shortly before midnight, though no one saw her fall. A search of the area was called off after three days due to poor weather conditions. Holloway, a student at Seagrave Comprehensive, was described by friends as “quiet but kind.” Police are not treating the incident as suspicious.* Mars read it twice. Then she snapped a photo with her phone and sent it to Lola. *This her?* Lola’s reply was instant. *OH MY GOD* *WHERE R U* *IM COMING* Mars sighed and texted back: *Library. Hurry up.* --- Lola arrived ten minutes later, breathless, her eyeliner smudged like she’d been crying. She shoved a crumpled printout into Mars’s hands. “I found this online,” she said. “It’s from, like, a true crime forum. Some guy was talking about Debs.” Mars skimmed the post. *My grandad was a fisherman back in the 80s. He said Debra Holloway didn’t drown. He said she was pushed. Said there was a party that night, and some bloke got handsy with her, and she threatened to tell his missus. Next thing anyone knew, she was gone. Cops never looked into it. Too busy covering up for the rich kids who were there.* Mars looked up. “This is bullshit.” “Is it?” Lola’s eyes were wide. “Mars, what if it’s *true*?” “What if it’s not? What if some random bloke on the internet just made it up for clicks?” “But what if he didn’t?” Mars rubbed her temples. “Lola, even if it *is* true, what does it have to do with the emojis?” “I don’t know!” Lola threw her hands up. “But it’s *something*. It’s a *clue*.” Mars exhaled. “Fine. Where do we even start?” Lola grinned. “Mr. Puddlefoot.” --- Mr. Puddlefoot lived in a caravan at the edge of the beach, between a boarded-up arcade and a rusted ice cream van that hadn’t moved in twenty years. The caravan was held together with duct tape and prayer, its windows fogged with condensation. A string of seashells hung from the awning, clacking in the wind. Mars knocked. No answer. Lola knocked again, harder. “Mr. Puddlefoot! It’s Lola Dawson! I need to ask you something!” A long pause. Then the door creaked open, revealing a gaunt old man with wild white hair and a pipe clamped between his teeth. He squinted at them. “You’re that Dawson girl,” he said. “The one who set fire to the bin.” Lola flushed. “That was an *accident*.” “Hmph.” Mr. Puddlefoot chewed on his pipe. “What do you want?” “We need to talk to you about Debs Holloway,” Mars said. Mr. Puddlefoot went very still. Then he stepped back, pulling the door open wider. “Get in. Before the old girl sees you.” Mars and Lola exchanged a glance. Then they stepped inside. The caravan smelled like damp wool and old books. Every surface was covered in clutter—newspaper clippings, seashells, a jar of something pickled that Mars didn’t want to identify. Mr. Puddlefoot gestured to a pair of folding chairs, then sat down heavily on a stool. “Debs Holloway,” he said. “Aye. I remember her.” Lola leaned forward. “What happened to her?” Mr. Puddlefoot’s eyes darkened. “The sea took her.” “That’s not an answer,” Mars said. “It’s the only one I’ve got.” He tapped his pipe against the edge of the table, sending ash scattering. “She was a quiet thing. Kept to herself. Used to sit on the pier and draw the waves. Said she was gonna be a marine biologist one day.” He chuckled, a dry, rattling sound. “Never got the chance.” “Do you think she drowned?” Lola asked. Mr. Puddlefoot’s gaze flicked to the window, where the sea glinted in the distance. “The sea don’t forget,” he said. “And neither do I.” Mars frowned. “What’s that supposed to mean?” “It means some things aren’t meant to be dug up, girl.” He stood abruptly. “Now get out. I’ve got things to do.” Lola opened her mouth to protest, but Mars grabbed her arm and pulled her toward the door. “Thanks for your time,” she muttered. Mr. Puddlefoot didn’t answer. He was already shuffling toward the back of the caravan, muttering to himself. --- The police station was a squat brick building next to the post office, its windows grimy with salt spray. DI Farley was at the front desk, frowning at a stack of paperwork. He looked up when Mars and Lola walked in, his expression souring. “You two again,” he said. “Us two,” Mars agreed. “What do you want?” “We need to talk to you about Old Man Higgins,” Lola said. Farley sighed. “It was an accident. He slipped on the pier. End of story.” “But—” “No buts.” Farley pinched the bridge of his nose. “Look, I get it. You’re bored. You want something to do. But this isn’t a game. People don’t just *fall* and die for no reason.” “What if it *was* for a reason?” Mars asked. Farley’s eyes narrowed. “What’s that supposed to mean?” Mars hesitated. Then she pulled out her phone and showed him the emoji texts. Farley stared at the screen. His face didn’t change, but something flickered in his eyes—something like recognition. “Where’d you get this?” “Some number,” Mars said. “It said *Debs*.” Farley went very still. “Debs?” “Yeah. Like, short for Debra.” Farley’s jaw tightened. “I know what it’s short for.” Mars and Lola exchanged a glance. “You knew her,” Mars said. Farley didn’t answer. Lola leaned forward. “DI Farley, if there’s something you’re not telling us—” “There’s nothing to tell.” Farley’s voice was sharp. “Now get out. I’ve got work to do.” Mars opened her mouth to argue, but Farley was already turning away, shuffling papers with exaggerated focus. Lola tugged on her sleeve. “Come on,” she whispered. “We’re not getting anything else out of him.” Mars let herself be pulled toward the door. But as they reached it, she glanced back. Farley was watching them. His face was unreadable. But his hands were shaking. --- The library was empty when they got back, Mrs. Hargreaves already locking up for the night. Mars led Lola to a corner table, where a stack of old newspapers sat waiting. They’d found them in the archives, yellowed and brittle with age. “Okay,” Lola said, flipping open the first one. “Let’s find everything we can on Debs.” Mars nodded and pulled out her phone. She typed *Debra Holloway* into the search bar and hit enter. The first result was a local news article from 1987. *Teenager Missing After Pier Incident.* Mars clicked on it. The article was short, just a few paragraphs. But at the bottom, there was a photo. A grainy shot of a group of teenagers, laughing, their arms slung around each other. In the center, a girl with dark hair and a shy smile—Debs. Mars’s breath caught. Because standing next to her, grinning at the camera, was a younger DI Farley. --- Mars’s phone buzzed. She looked down. **Unknown number:** *You’re running out of time.*
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates solid craft in several areas while falling short of excellence in others. The writing successfully advances the mystery plot through logical investigative steps - library research, interviewing Mr. Puddlefoot, visiting the police station - that feel natural rather than contrived. The pacing is well-managed, building tension through accumulating clues and ending with an effective hook revealing DI Farley's connection to Debs. The character work shows genuine understanding of the established personalities. Mars's skeptical but curious nature comes through clearly, particularly in her reluctance to believe conspiracy theories while still pursuing leads. Her internal voice maintains the established sarcastic tone without becoming grating. Lola's dramatic tendencies and research obsession are well-deployed, making her useful to the plot while keeping her character flaws visible. DI Farley's evasiveness and the subtle hints at his deeper knowledge create appropriate tension. However, the writing suffers from several technical weaknesses. The dialogue often feels stilted and unnatural, particularly in exchanges like "What if it's true?" / "What if it's not?" which read more like placeholder conversation than authentic teenage speech. The prose occasionally veers into overwrought territory with phrases like "clutched in her hand like a grenade with the pin pulled" - a metaphor that doesn't quite work since grenades explode when the pin is pulled, not when clutched. The chapter follows its plan faithfully, hitting all the required beats: research, Mr. Puddlefoot's cryptic responses, DI Farley's evasiveness, and the revelation of his connection to Debs. The mystery deepens appropriately without becoming convoluted. The supernatural elements remain subtle, maintaining the established tone. Some moments feel underdeveloped - Mr. Puddlefoot's characterization relies heavily on generic "mysterious old man" tropes, and his dialogue ("The sea don't forget") borders on cliché. The library research sequence, while necessary, lacks the specificity that would make it feel authentic rather than perfunctory. The chapter maintains coherence throughout and advances both plot and character development. The writing demonstrates competence but lacks the distinctive voice and sharp observational detail that would elevate it to a higher level. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 13 Tell-Don't-Show: 12 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 11 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 11 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14 Characters Consistent with Profile: 16 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 4: The Second Victim** Mars didn’t tell Lola about the photo. She didn’t tell her about Farley, either. Not yet. Not until she knew what it meant. Instead, she spent the night staring at the ceiling, her phone clutched in her hand like it might explode. The emojis kept coming. Three drops. Over and over. Like a countdown. She blocked the number. It didn’t help. --- The next morning, The Golden Fry was packed. Tourists in neon windbreakers jostled for space at the counter, their voices loud and bright. Mars moved on autopilot, scooping chips, taking orders, ignoring the way her hands shook when she reached for the fryer. Lola burst in at noon, her face pale. “Mars,” she said. “Tasha’s dead.” Mars froze. “What?” “Choked. On a chip.” Lola’s voice was high, breathless. “At *your* shop.” Mars’s stomach lurched. “That’s not—” “It’s the second one,” Lola interrupted. “Three drops, three deaths. Mars, it’s *happening*.” Mars wanted to argue. Wanted to say it was a coincidence. Wanted to laugh it off. But then she remembered the way Tasha had looked at her yesterday, smug and superior, like she was better than everyone else. And now she was dead. --- The group chat was chaos. **Josh:** TASHA’S DEAD **Danny:** no way **Lola:** THE SECOND BLOOD DROP HAS BEEN SPILLED **Tasha’s Best Friend (new to chat):** this isnt funny **Josh:** i told u it was real **Danny:** wait how did she die **Lola:** CHOKED ON A CHIP **Danny:** lmao **Tasha’s Best Friend:** I HATE U ALL Mars locked her phone. She didn’t want to look at it again. But she did. Because the texts kept coming. --- Mars found Lola outside, leaning against the seawall, her hands wrapped around a half-eaten pasty. She looked up when Mars approached, her eyes red-rimmed. “This isn’t funny anymore,” she said. “I know.” “People are *dying*.” “I know.” Lola’s voice cracked. “What if it’s *us* next?” Mars didn’t answer. She didn’t know what to say. Lola wiped her eyes with the back of her hand. “We have to do something.” “Like what?” “I don’t know!” Lola threw her hands up. “But we can’t just *wait* for it to happen again.” Mars exhaled. “Fine. What do you suggest?” Lola’s eyes lit up. “We go to the pier.” “What?” “The pier. Where it all started.” Lola grabbed Mars’s arm. “We go there. Tonight. And we *find out* what’s going on.” Mars pulled away. “That’s a terrible idea.” “It’s the *only* idea.” Mars looked at the pier, its wooden planks dark with seawater, the waves crashing against its supports. She thought of Debs. Of Farley. Of the way her hands had shaken when she’d seen that photo. “Fine,” she said. “But we go at midnight. And we don’t stay long.” Lola grinned. “Deal.” --- Mars told her mum she was staying at Lola’s. Lola told her nan she was staying at Mars’s. Neither of them mentioned the pier. They met at 11:45 PM, at the edge of the promenade. The wind was sharp, carrying the scent of salt and diesel. The pier loomed ahead, its skeletal frame silhouetted against the dark water. “Ready?” Lola asked. Mars wasn’t. But she nodded anyway. --- The pier was empty. The boards creaked under their feet, the sound swallowed by the crash of waves below. Mars’s heart hammered in her chest. She kept expecting something to jump out at them—a shadow, a whisper, a hand reaching up from the water. But there was nothing. “This is stupid,” she muttered. “Shh.” Lola was scanning the planks, her flashlight cutting through the dark. “We’re looking for clues.” “Like what?” “I don’t know! Something *weird*.” Mars rolled her eyes. But she started looking anyway. They walked the length of the pier, their footsteps echoing. The wind howled around them, tugging at their clothes. Mars’s skin prickled. Then she saw it. A dark smear on the railing. Like blood. But it wasn’t blood. It was too thin. Too *wet*. She reached out, touched it with her fingertips. Seawater. “Lola,” she said. Lola turned. “What?” Mars held up her fingers. “This.” Lola’s flashlight flickered over the railing. “What is it?” “Water.” Mars’s voice was quiet. “From the sea.” Lola frowned. “So?” “So,” Mars said, “it hasn’t rained tonight.” A pause. Then Lola’s breath hitched. “Mars.” Mars turned. Standing at the end of the pier, half-hidden in shadow, was a figure. A girl. She was pale, her hair dark and damp, her clothes clinging to her like she’d just stepped out of the water. A red scarf was draped around her shoulders, fluttering in the wind. Debs. Mars’s blood turned to ice. The girl raised a hand, pointing at them. Then she opened her mouth and screamed. --- Mars ran. She didn’t think. Didn’t look back. Just ran, her boots pounding against the planks, her breath coming in ragged gasps. Lola was right behind her, her flashlight bouncing wildly. They didn’t stop until they reached the promenade. Then Mars doubled over, her hands on her knees, her heart hammering. “What the *hell* was that?” Lola gasped. Mars didn’t answer. She was too busy staring at her phone. Because the texts had started again. **Unknown number:** *You’re next.* **Unknown number:** *Mars.* **Unknown number:** *I see you.*
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates solid technical competence but falls short of the ambitious vision outlined in the plan. The writing follows the basic plot beats effectively - Tasha's death, the group chat chaos, and the pier confrontation - but lacks the sophisticated character work and tonal balance promised. The characterization shows some strengths, particularly Mars's internal conflict and practical skepticism, but doesn't fully capitalize on the detailed profiles provided. Mars feels authentic in her reluctance and fear, but her voice lacks the sharp wit and defensive sarcasm that should define her. Lola comes across as generically dramatic rather than the complex, attention-seeking but brilliant researcher described in the profile. The dialogue is functional but rarely sparkles with the regional authenticity or character-specific speech patterns outlined in the plan. The chapter's structure works well, building tension through the group chat chaos to the pier confrontation. However, the horror elements feel somewhat conventional - the ghostly figure at the pier's end is a familiar trope executed competently but without particular innovation. The plan promised "subtle and atmospheric" horror, but the screaming ghost feels more like a standard jump scare. The group chat sequences are the chapter's strongest element, capturing authentic teenage digital panic with believable escalation from shock to morbid humor to genuine distress. This feels true to the plan's vision of "how teens actually freak out." The writing style is clean and readable, avoiding purple prose or forced metaphors. However, it also lacks the distinctive voice promised - the "conversational, sarcastic, but vulnerable" narration reads more neutrally than expected. The dark comedy elements are present but understated, missing opportunities for the sharper satirical edge the plan envisioned. The chapter follows its structural plan faithfully but doesn't achieve the tonal sophistication or character depth that would elevate it from competent to compelling. It reads like a solid first draft that needs another pass to inject the personality and wit that would make it truly engaging. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 12 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 12 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 11 Amateurish: 9 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 11 Characters Consistent with Profile: 10 Followed Chapter Plan: 15 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 5: The Truth About Debs** Mars didn’t sleep. She sat on the edge of her bed, her phone clutched in her hand, the glow of the screen casting long shadows across her face. The texts kept coming. *Mars.* *I see you.* *You can’t hide.* She blocked the number. Again. It didn’t help. --- The next morning, she found Lola waiting outside The Golden Fry, her face pale, her hands wrapped around a takeaway coffee. She looked like she hadn’t slept either. “You got the texts too,” Mars said. Lola nodded. “Yeah.” “What do they mean?” “I don’t know.” Lola’s voice was quiet. “But I think… I think Debs is trying to tell us something.” Mars exhaled. “Like what?” “I don’t know!” Lola threw her hands up. “But we have to figure it out. Before it’s too late.” Mars didn’t answer. She was too busy staring at the pier, its wooden planks dark with seawater. The memory of last night—of the girl in the red scarf, her mouth open in a silent scream—was burned into her brain. She needed answers. And she knew where to find them. --- Debs’ old friend still lived in town. Her name was Sophie Carter, and she worked at the library. Mars had seen her around—tall, dark-haired, always with a book in her hand. She was older now, in her fifties, but Mars recognised her from the photo in the newspaper. The one with Farley. Mars waited until Sophie was alone, shelving books in the local history section. Then she walked up to her. “Sophie Carter?” Sophie turned, her expression guarded. “Yes?” “I need to talk to you about Debs Holloway.” Sophie went very still. “Why?” “Because I think she’s trying to tell me something.” Sophie’s eyes flickered. “What do you mean?” Mars pulled out her phone, showed her the texts. Sophie stared at the screen. Her face paled. “Where did you get this?” she whispered. “It just… started coming,” Mars said. “Three blood drops. Then *Debs*. Then warnings. And then—” She hesitated. “And then people started dying.” Sophie’s hands shook. “That’s not possible.” “It’s happening,” Mars said. “I saw her. On the pier. She was—” She swallowed. “She was pointing at me.” Sophie’s breath hitched. “You saw her?” “Yes.” Sophie closed her eyes. “Oh god.” “Please,” Mars said. “I need to know what happened to her.” Sophie opened her eyes. “Why?” “Because I think she’s trying to *warn* us.” Sophie exhaled, long and slow. Then she nodded. “Fine. But not here.” --- They went to a café on the seafront, a quiet place with peeling wallpaper and chipped mugs. Sophie ordered tea. Mars ordered coffee, black. Sophie wrapped her hands around her mug, her knuckles white. “Debs and I were friends,” she said. “Best friends. We did everything together. Then… then she died.” “What happened?” Mars asked. Sophie’s gaze flickered to the window, where the sea glinted in the distance. “It was after a party. A bunch of us were on the pier, drinking, messing around. Debs was quiet that night. She kept staring at the water, like she was waiting for something.” Sophie’s voice dropped. “Then she slipped.” “Slipped?” “Yeah. The railing was loose. She just… fell.” Sophie’s eyes filled with tears. “We never found her body.” Mars’s stomach twisted. “Do you think it was an accident?” Sophie hesitated. “I don’t know. Maybe. But…” She trailed off. “But what?” Sophie’s voice was barely a whisper. “The night she died, she told me she’d been having dreams. Dreams about three drops of blood. She said it was a warning.” She looked at Mars. “She said someone was going to die.” Mars’s breath caught. “Who?” “I don’t know.” Sophie’s hands trembled. “She never told me.” Mars exhaled. “Do you think… do you think she’s trying to warn us now?” Sophie didn’t answer. But the look on her face said everything. --- Mars found Lola waiting outside The Golden Fry, her arms wrapped around herself, her face pale. “Well?” Lola asked. Mars told her everything. Lola’s eyes widened. “So the emojis *are* a warning.” “Yeah.” “But a warning about what?” “I don’t know.” Mars’s voice was quiet. “But I think… I think Debs is trying to stop it.” Lola frowned. “Stop what?” “The deaths.” Mars looked at the pier, its wooden planks dark with seawater. “She’s not trying to *kill* anyone. She’s trying to *save* them.” Lola’s breath hitched. “Then why is she scaring us?” “Because we’re not listening.” Lola was quiet for a long moment. Then she pulled out her phone, typed something, and hit send. “What are you doing?” Mars asked. “I’m texting her.” Lola’s voice was steady. “I’m telling her we *are* listening.” Mars’s phone buzzed. She looked down. **Unknown number:** *You can’t stop it.* Mars’s breath caught. **Mars:** *How do we try?* A pause. Then— **Debs:** *You have to listen.* Mars stared at the screen. “What does that even *mean*?” Lola’s eyes were wide. “I don’t know. But we have to figure it out. Before it’s too late.” Mars nodded. But her hands were shaking. Because she had a feeling they were already out of time. --- That night, Mars dreamed of the sea. She was standing on the pier, the wind howling around her, the waves crashing against the supports. Debs was there, her red scarf fluttering in the wind, her eyes sad. *You have to listen,* she whispered. Then she reached out, her fingers brushing Mars’s cheek. Mars woke up with a gasp, her heart hammering in her chest. Her phone was buzzing. She looked down. **Unknown number:** *Help me.* Mars’s breath caught. She typed back. **Mars:** *How?* No reply. But then her phone buzzed again. A photo. A grainy, black-and-white shot of the pier, taken from the water. Standing at the end, her red scarf fluttering in the wind, was Debs. And next to her, his arm slung around her shoulders, grinning at the camera, was DI Farley.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter represents a significant departure from the established tone and character work outlined in the detailed plan. The writing suffers from several fundamental issues that undermine the story's darkly comic British YA premise. The most glaring problem is the complete abandonment of Mars's established voice and personality. The plan describes her as having a "conversational, sarcastic, but vulnerable" voice with dry humor as armor, yet this chapter presents her as a generic, humorless protagonist speaking in flat, exposition-heavy dialogue. Lines like "I need to talk to you about Debs Holloway" and "Because I think she's trying to warn us" could come from any supernatural thriller - there's no trace of the specific, regionally-grounded character described in the profile. The chapter also abandons the darkly comic tone that was central to the story's identity. The plan emphasized balancing "eerie folklore, dry British humour, and emotional realism," but this chapter is relentlessly serious and melodramatic. There's no sign of the group chat hysteria, the absurd overreactions, or Mars's defensive sarcasm that were supposed to provide the story's distinctive flavor. Structurally, the chapter rushes through major plot revelations without proper development. Sophie's exposition dump about Debs's death feels perfunctory and lacks the messy, human quality the plan called for. The dialogue throughout is stilted and functional rather than naturalistic - characters speak in complete sentences to convey information rather than in the interrupted, regional speech patterns described in the character profiles. The supernatural elements become heavy-handed and lose their subtlety. The plan called for "subtle and atmospheric" horror, but the direct texting with the ghost and the dramatic photograph revelation feel more like generic paranormal fiction than the nuanced approach outlined. The ending photograph twist, while potentially intriguing, comes across as a manufactured shock rather than an organic development. The writing also suffers from repetitive sentence structures and lacks the specific, grounded details that would bring the seaside setting to life. Descriptions like "the sea glinted in the distance" are generic rather than capturing the particular atmosphere of this "shithole-by-the-sea." Most critically, the chapter fails to serve its stated purpose in the plan. Chapter 5 was meant to reveal that "The emojis aren't a threat—they're a warning" and show Mars realizing Debs is trying to prevent deaths. While this revelation occurs, it lacks emotional weight because the characters feel like plot devices rather than real people grappling with supernatural horror. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 6 Emotionally Engaging: 8 Compelling Plot: 10 Coherent: 14 Weak Dialogue: 15 Tell-Don't-Show: 14 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13 Amateurish: 13 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 5 Characters Consistent with Profile: 4 Followed Chapter Plan: 8 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 6

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 6: The Group Chat Takes Over** The next morning, the group chat was a warzone. **Lola:** WE HAVE TO DO SOMETHING **Josh:** like what **Tasha’s Best Friend (still in chat for some reason):** this is ur fault lola **Danny:** how is this lolas fault **Tasha’s Best Friend:** u started this **Lola:** I DIDNT START ANYTHING **Mars:** guys **Mars:** shut up A pause. Then— **Josh:** okay but what do we do **Lola:** we have to hold a vigil **Danny:** a what **Lola:** a vigil. for deb. to show her we care. **Josh:** we didnt even know her **Lola:** EXACTLY Mars sighed and locked her phone. She didn’t have the energy for this. But Lola wasn’t done. She burst into The Golden Fry at noon, her face flushed, her eyes wild. “We’re doing it tonight,” she announced. “At the pier. Eight o’clock.” Mars stared at her. “Doing what?” “The vigil!” Lola grabbed Mars’s arm. “Everyone’s coming. Even Tasha’s friends.” “Great,” Mars muttered. “That’ll go well.” “It will!” Lola insisted. “It’s a *sign* of respect.” Mars raised an eyebrow. “Respect for what?” “For Debs!” Lola threw her hands up. “Mars, we have to *do* something. Before someone else dies.” Mars exhaled. She didn’t want to go to a vigil. She didn’t want to stand on the pier at night, surrounded by people who didn’t even know Debs, pretending they cared. But she didn’t have a choice. Because the texts were still coming. And the third drop was next. --- The pier was packed. Dozens of kids from school milled around, their phones out, their voices loud. Some were crying. Some were laughing. Some were just there for the drama. Mars stood at the edge, her arms crossed, her stomach twisting. Lola was in the center of the crowd, holding a candle, her face solemn. “Thank you all for coming,” she said, her voice shaking. “Debs was… she was a good person. And we’re here to honor her memory.” A murmur rippled through the crowd. Mars rolled her eyes. Then she saw him. DI Farley, standing at the back, his arms crossed, his face unreadable. Their eyes met. Farley’s jaw tightened. Mars looked away. --- The vigil was a disaster. Someone started crying. Someone else started filming. A fight broke out between Tasha’s friends and a group of Year 10s. Lola tried to calm everyone down, but it was too late. The crowd was spiraling. Then someone screamed. Mars turned. A girl was pointing at the water. “There’s something in the sea!” The crowd surged forward, phones out, flashlights cutting through the dark. Mars pushed her way to the front, her heart hammering. Then she saw it. A shape in the water. Pale. Floating. Debs. Her red scarf fluttered in the current, her hair spread out around her like seaweed. Her eyes were open, staring up at the sky. Mars’s breath caught. Then someone else screamed. “It’s Mr. Puddlefoot!” Mars turned. Mr. Puddlefoot was sprawled on the pier, his eyes wide, his mouth open in a silent scream. A dark puddle spread beneath his head. Blood. The crowd erupted. Mars didn’t move. She couldn’t. Because she knew what this meant. Three drops. Three deaths. The cycle was complete. --- The group chat exploded. **Josh:** OH MY GOD MR PUDDLEFOOT IS DEAD **Danny:** no way **Tasha’s Best Friend:** this is ur fault lola **Lola:** I DIDNT DO ANYTHING **Josh:** u started this **Danny:** how is this lolas fault **Tasha’s Best Friend:** SHE STARTED THE BLOOD CULT **Lola:** IT WAS A VIGIL **Mars:** guys **Mars:** shut up **Mars:** we have to call the police A pause. Then— **Josh:** already did Mars looked up. DI Farley was pushing his way through the crowd, his face grim. He knelt beside Mr. Puddlefoot’s body, checked for a pulse, then stood and pulled out his radio. “Everyone back up,” he barked. “Now.” The crowd obeyed, their voices a low murmur. Farley’s eyes met Mars’s. She looked away. Because she knew. This wasn’t over. --- Mars found Lola at the edge of the pier, her face pale, her hands shaking. “This is my fault,” Lola whispered. “No, it’s not,” Mars said. “Yes, it is!” Lola’s voice cracked. “I started the group chat. I started the vigil. I *made* this happen.” “You didn’t make anything happen,” Mars said. “Debs did.” Lola looked at her. “What?” Mars hesitated. Then she pulled out her phone, showed Lola the photo. The one of Debs and Farley. Lola’s breath hitched. “Who’s that with her?” “DI Farley,” Mars said. Lola’s eyes widened. “He knew her?” “Yeah.” “Then why didn’t he say anything?” “I don’t know.” Mars’s voice was quiet. “But I think… I think he knows more than he’s letting on.” Lola was quiet for a long moment. Then she pulled out her phone, typed something, and hit send. “What are you doing?” Mars asked. “I’m texting Debs.” Lola’s voice was steady. “I’m telling her we’re sorry.” Mars’s phone buzzed. She looked down. **Unknown number:** *Too late.* Mars’s breath caught. **Mars:** *What do you want?* A pause. Then— **Debs:** *I just wanted someone to remember me.* Mars stared at the screen. Then her phone buzzed again. **Unknown number:** *Mars.* **Unknown number:** *You’re next.*
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively builds tension and chaos around the vigil scene while maintaining the story's darkly comic tone. The writing successfully balances multiple narrative threads - the group chat hysteria, the vigil disaster, and the supernatural elements - without losing coherence. The group chat sequences feel authentically teenage, capturing the way online drama spirals with realistic dialogue patterns and escalating blame. The characterizations remain consistent with the established profiles: Lola's desperate need for attention and validation, Mars's reluctant involvement and growing understanding, and the crowd's performative grief for someone they never knew. The vigil scene builds effectively to its climax, with the discovery of both Debs's ghostly presence and Mr. Puddlefoot's death creating genuine dramatic impact. The revelation that DI Farley knew Debs adds another layer of mystery without feeling forced. The ending maintains the supernatural threat while advancing the plot toward its conclusion. However, there are some weaknesses. The pacing occasionally feels rushed, particularly in the transition from vigil to the deaths. Some dialogue, especially in the group chat, borders on repetitive. The supernatural elements, while atmospheric, sometimes lack the subtlety promised in the plan - Debs appearing in the water feels more overtly ghostly than the previous whispers and shadows. The writing avoids purple prose and forced metaphors, maintaining a conversational tone appropriate for YA fiction. The dark comedy emerges naturally from the characters' reactions rather than being imposed by the narrator. The chapter successfully follows its planned structure while building toward the story's climax. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 7: The Confrontation** Mars didn’t go home. She couldn’t. Not after that text. *You’re next.* She walked instead, her boots pounding against the pavement, her breath coming in ragged gasps. The streets were empty, the only sound the distant crash of waves against the seawall. She ended up at the pier. Again. She didn’t want to be there. But she didn’t know where else to go. The police tape fluttered in the wind, cordoning off the spot where Mr. Puddlefoot had died. Mars ducked under it, her heart hammering in her chest. The planks were still damp with blood. She didn’t look down. She walked to the end of the pier, where the railing was loose, where Debs had fallen. The wind howled around her, tugging at her clothes, her hair. Then she saw it. A red scarf, tangled in the railing. Debs’ scarf. Mars reached out, her fingers brushing the fabric. It was damp. Cold. Like the sea. “Mars.” She spun around. Lola stood behind her, her face pale, her eyes wide. “What are you doing here?” Mars asked. “I followed you.” Lola’s voice was quiet. “I was worried.” Mars didn’t answer. Lola stepped forward, her gaze flickering to the scarf. “Is that—?” “Yeah.” Lola exhaled. “Mars, we have to do something.” “Like what?” “I don’t know.” Lola’s hands shook. “But we can’t just *wait* for it to happen again.” Mars looked at the scarf, her stomach twisting. “She’s not trying to kill us.” “What?” “Debs.” Mars’s voice was steady. “She’s not trying to kill anyone. She’s trying to *warn* us.” Lola frowned. “Warn us about what?” “I don’t know.” Mars looked at the sea, its dark waters churning below. “But I think… I think she’s trying to stop it.” Lola was quiet for a long moment. Then she pulled out her phone, typed something, and hit send. “What are you doing?” Mars asked. “I’m texting her.” Lola’s voice was quiet. “I’m telling her we *are* listening.” Mars’s phone buzzed. She looked down. **Unknown number:** *You’re too late.* Mars’s breath caught. **Mars:** *How do we stop it?* A pause. Then— **Debs:** *You have to listen.* Mars stared at the screen. “What does that even *mean*?” Lola’s eyes were wide. “I don’t know. But we have to figure it out. Before it’s too late.” Mars nodded. But her hands were shaking. Because she had a feeling they were already out of time. --- The crowd arrived an hour later. Dozens of kids from school, their phones out, their voices loud. Some were crying. Some were laughing. Some were just there for the drama. Lola stepped forward, her voice shaking. “Thank you all for coming. Debs was—” “This is bullshit.” Mars turned. Tasha’s best friend stood at the edge of the crowd, her arms crossed, her face twisted in a sneer. “Debs is dead,” she said. “And it’s *your* fault, Lola.” The crowd murmured. Lola’s face paled. “What?” “You started this.” Tasha’s best friend stepped forward. “The group chat. The vigil. You *made* this happen.” “That’s not true!” Lola’s voice cracked. “Yes, it is.” Tasha’s best friend’s eyes were cold. “And now Mr. Puddlefoot is dead because of you.” The crowd erupted. Mars stepped forward. “Shut up.” Tasha’s best friend turned to her. “Or what?” Mars didn’t answer. Because then she saw her. Debs. Standing at the end of the pier, her red scarf fluttering in the wind, her eyes sad. Mars’s breath caught. Debs raised a hand, pointing at them. Then she opened her mouth and screamed. --- The crowd scattered. Kids screamed, phones clattered to the ground, voices rose in panic. Mars didn’t move. She couldn’t. Because Debs was walking toward her. Her feet didn’t touch the ground. She stopped in front of Mars, her eyes sad, her voice a whisper. *“You didn’t listen.”* Mars’s breath hitched. “We’re trying.” *“Too late.”* Debs’s voice was quiet. *“They never listen.”* Mars’s hands shook. “What do you want?” Debs looked at the scarf in Mars’s hands. *“I just wanted someone to remember me.”* Mars’s throat tightened. “I remember you.” Debs’s eyes filled with tears. *“Do you?”* Mars didn’t answer. Because then she saw it. A shadow, moving behind Debs. A figure. DI Farley. He stood at the edge of the pier, his face pale, his eyes wide. “Debs,” he whispered. Debs turned. Farley’s breath hitched. “I’m so sorry.” Debs didn’t answer. She just looked at him, her eyes sad. Then she turned back to Mars. *“You have to stop it.”* Mars’s breath caught. “Stop what?” Debs didn’t answer. She just reached out, her fingers brushing Mars’s cheek. Then she was gone. --- The pier was empty. The crowd had scattered. The only sound was the crash of waves against the supports. Mars stood there, her heart hammering in her chest, the red scarf clutched in her hands. Farley stepped forward, his face grim. “Mars,” he said. “We need to talk.” Mars didn’t answer. She just looked at the scarf, her hands shaking. Because she knew. This wasn’t over. Not yet.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter represents a significant tonal shift from the darkly comic British YA fiction established in the prompt and plan. The writing abandons the dry humor and sarcastic voice that defined Mars' character in favor of a generic supernatural thriller approach. The chapter fails to follow its own plan in several critical ways. The plan called for Mars to "rush to the pier to warn the vigil" about a crowd convinced by Lola to "sacrifice a red scarf," but instead we get Mars wandering alone to the pier where she finds the scarf already there. The planned crowd dynamics - turning on Mars for "working with the ghost" - are replaced with a much simpler confrontation about blame. Most importantly, the plan specified that "the humour fades as the loneliness of the ghost takes centre stage," but there was no established humor to fade from, and the execution feels melodramatic rather than genuinely melancholic. Character consistency suffers significantly. Mars, established as sarcastic and defensive, becomes passive and mystical. Her voice loses all the sharp wit and regional flavor that defined her. Lola appears briefly but without her characteristic dramatic overreaction and conspiracy theorizing. DI Farley's appearance feels perfunctory rather than meaningful. The dialogue is particularly weak, falling into generic supernatural thriller territory. Lines like "You have to stop it" and "I just wanted someone to remember me" are clichéd and lack the specific voice established for these characters. The text exchanges feel mechanical rather than emotionally resonant. The supernatural elements are handled heavy-handedly. The ghost's manifestation - walking without touching ground, making people scatter with a scream - reads more like a horror movie than the subtle, atmospheric haunting described in the plan. The red scarf becomes an obvious supernatural prop rather than a meaningful connection to the character. The writing shows technical competence but lacks the distinctive voice and tonal complexity the story requires. Sentences like "The planks were still damp with blood" and "Her feet didn't touch the ground" are functional but unremarkable. The pacing feels rushed, jumping between emotional beats without proper development. The chapter does maintain basic coherence and follows some supernatural thriller conventions competently, but it fundamentally misunderstands what made the planned story distinctive - the balance of humor and horror, the specific character voices, and the social commentary about teenage hysteria and small-town dynamics. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 6 Emotionally Engaging: 8 Compelling Plot: 9 Coherent: 14 Weak Dialogue: 15 Tell-Don't-Show: 12 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 16 Amateurish: 14 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 5 Characters Consistent with Profile: 4 Followed Chapter Plan: 3 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 4

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 8: The Aftermath** The next morning, the town acted like nothing had happened. The pier was quiet. The police tape was gone. The group chat was silent. Mars sat on the edge of her bed, staring at her phone. The last text from Debs still glowed on the screen. *You have to stop it.* She didn’t know how. She didn’t even know if she could. But she had to try. --- She found Lola at the chip shop, her face pale, her hands wrapped around a cup of tea. “You okay?” Mars asked. Lola shook her head. “No.” Mars sat down beside her. “Me neither.” Lola’s eyes filled with tears. “I keep thinking about Mr. Puddlefoot. And Tasha. And—” She swallowed. “And Debs.” Mars didn’t answer. Because she was thinking the same thing. Lola wiped her eyes. “What do we do now?” Mars pulled the red scarf from her pocket. “We finish this.” --- They went to the pier. The wind was sharp, the sea churning below. The planks creaked under their feet. Mars walked to the end, where the railing was loose, where Debs had fallen. She knelt, her fingers brushing the wood. Then she tied the scarf around the railing. Lola watched, her eyes wide. “What are you doing?” Mars didn’t answer. She just looked at the sea, her throat tight. “I remember you,” she whispered. A pause. Then— A whisper. *Thank you.* Mars’s breath caught. She turned. Debs stood behind her, her red scarf fluttering in the wind, her eyes sad. “You’re still here,” Mars said. Debs nodded. *“Not for long.”* Mars’s throat tightened. “What do we do?” Debs looked at the sea. *“You let me go.”* Mars didn’t understand. But then she did. She reached out, her fingers brushing Debs’ cheek. Debs smiled. Then she was gone. --- The town moved on. The group chat was deleted. The vigil was forgotten. The deaths were ruled accidents. Mars went back to work at The Golden Fry. Lola started a new conspiracy theory TikTok. DI Farley retired, moved to Spain, never spoke of Debs again. Mars kept the scarf. She didn’t know why. But sometimes, when the wind howled off the sea, she thought she heard a whisper. *I remember you too.* --- One night, Mars was closing up the chip shop when her phone buzzed. She pulled it out. A text. **Unknown number:** 🩸 Mars stared at the screen. Then she blocked the number. Again. She turned off her phone and went home. The next morning, the text was still there. Like clockwork. Like the tide. Like the sea. Always coming back.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This final chapter attempts to provide closure to the supernatural mystery while maintaining the story's darkly comic tone, but it suffers from several significant weaknesses that undermine its effectiveness. The chapter's structure follows the planned outline reasonably well, showing the town's return to normalcy and Mars's final confrontation with Debs. However, the execution feels rushed and emotionally hollow. The opening section effectively captures the town's collective amnesia about the previous night's hysteria, which aligns with the story's themes about how people ignore uncomfortable truths. The dialogue is notably weak throughout. Exchanges like "You okay?" / "No." / "Me neither." are painfully generic and lack the distinctive voice established for these characters in the profiles. Mars, who was characterized as having sharp, sarcastic wit, speaks in bland, forgettable phrases. Lola's dialogue similarly lacks her established dramatic flair and research obsession. The conversation feels like placeholder text rather than authentic character interaction. The supernatural resolution with Debs is particularly problematic. The ghost's sudden appearance and equally sudden departure feels unearned and dramatically inert. The whispered "Thank you" and "Not for long" responses are clichéd ghost-story dialogue that adds nothing meaningful to the character or themes. The moment where Mars "lets her go" by touching her cheek is a tired supernatural trope executed without emotional weight or narrative logic. The chapter's attempt at ambiguity with the final emoji text falls flat because it feels like an arbitrary twist rather than a meaningful continuation of the story's themes. The repetitive structure of "Like clockwork. Like the tide. Like the sea. Always coming back." is forced poetry that doesn't enhance the meaning—it's empty stylistic flourish. The writing frequently tells rather than shows, particularly in passages like "The town moved on" followed by a list of what each character did. This summary approach robs the ending of emotional impact and feels like the author rushing to tie up loose ends rather than exploring the characters' genuine responses to their experiences. The characterization is inconsistent with the established profiles. Mars's passive acceptance of the supernatural elements contradicts her established skepticism and defensive sarcasm. The chapter lacks the "darkly comic" tone promised in the prompt, instead settling for generic melancholy. While the chapter attempts to address the story's themes about miscommunication and loneliness, it does so through obvious symbolism (the red scarf) and heavy-handed metaphors rather than through character development or meaningful plot resolution. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 6 Emotionally Engaging: 7 Compelling Plot: 8 Coherent: 12 Weak Dialogue: 15 Tell-Don't-Show: 14 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 16 Amateurish: 14 Purple Prose: 12 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 15 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 8 Characters Consistent with Profile: 7 Followed Chapter Plan: 14 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 11

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This darkly comic British YA fiction piece demonstrates strong structural ambition but suffers from significant execution issues that undermine its effectiveness. The story follows Mars, a chip shop worker, who receives mysterious blood emoji texts that seem connected to supernatural occurrences and deaths in her seaside town. The piece succeeds in establishing a distinctly British seaside setting with authentic details like The Golden Fry chip shop, the pier, and local dialect. The author captures the mundane bleakness of small-town life effectively, and the supernatural elements are woven into this realistic backdrop with some skill. The mystery structure is solid, building from the initial text messages to revelations about Debs Holloway's death in the 1980s. However, the execution reveals several critical weaknesses. The dialogue often feels stilted and unnatural, particularly in the group chat sequences which read more like plot exposition than authentic teenage communication. Characters frequently speak in ways that serve the plot rather than reflecting genuine personality or emotional states. Mars and Lola's conversations often lack the natural flow of real friendship, with responses that feel mechanically constructed to advance the mystery. The characterization is disappointingly shallow throughout. Mars remains largely reactive rather than proactive, and her emotional responses feel muted given the supernatural terror she's experiencing. Lola is reduced to a conspiracy-theory stereotype without much depth beyond her obsessive personality. The supporting characters like DI Farley and Sophie Carter exist primarily as exposition delivery devices rather than fully realized people. The pacing suffers from uneven development, with some chapters rushing through major plot points while others dwell on repetitive elements. The group chat sequences, while initially atmospheric, become tedious and don't serve the story's progression effectively. The supernatural elements escalate without sufficient emotional grounding, making the climactic encounters feel hollow rather than genuinely frightening or moving. The piece attempts dark comedy but largely fails to achieve it. The humor feels forced rather than emerging naturally from character or situation. The deaths of secondary characters like Tasha and Mr. Puddlefoot lack emotional weight, making them feel more like plot devices than tragic events that should impact the protagonists. The resolution is particularly weak, with Debs' motivations and the supernatural mechanics remaining frustratingly vague. The ending attempts profundity but feels unearned given the shallow character development throughout. The final suggestion that the cycle continues lacks impact because we haven't been sufficiently invested in the characters' journey. While the piece demonstrates competent prose and maintains narrative coherence, it reads more like a competent first draft than a polished work. The supernatural mystery elements are handled adequately but without the depth or originality needed to elevate the material beyond genre conventions. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 12 Nuanced Characters: 8 Pacing: 11 World Building: 15 Compelling Plot: 12 Emotionally Engaging: 9 Coherent: 14 Weak Dialogue: 14 Tell-Don't-Show: 13 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 9 Unearned Transformations: 12 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 10 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16
Avg Final Item Score: 50.7/100
+ Space Western — Cargo Unknown (Chapter Avg: 62.9 | Final: 50.4)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something's... moving in that crate we picked up.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something&#x27;s... moving in that crate we picked up. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# **Writing Plan for *Space Western: "Something's Moving in That Crate"*** **Scope:** 8 chapters (~1,000 words each) --- ## **# Brainstorming** ### **1. Genre & Tone** - **Space Western:** Gritty, frontier justice, morally gray characters, isolation, survival. - **Horror/Sci-Fi Hybrid:** Cosmic horror (Lovecraftian), body horror, alien infestation, psychological dread. - **Action-Adventure:** High-stakes chase, shootouts, heists, betrayals. - **Mystery/Noir:** Slow-burn investigation, unreliable narrator, hidden conspiracies. - **Comedy (Dark or Satirical):** Absurdity, incompetent crew, bureaucratic nightmare. **Possible Tone Blends:** - *Firefly* meets *Alien* (crew of misfits vs. something inhuman). - *The Thing* in space (paranoia, body horror, survival). - *Cowboy Bebop* with a horror twist (jazz, bounty hunting, eerie cargo). - *Deadwood* in zero-G (political intrigue, backstabbing, corruption). --- ### **2. Characters (Potential Crew of the Ship)** **The Captain:** - **Ex-Military (Disgraced):** Hardened, pragmatic, but hiding guilt. - **Smuggler with a Code:** Robin Hood-esque, but morally flexible. - **Corporate Puppet:** Just following orders, but the crate changes everything. - **Reluctant Leader:** Never wanted command, but the crew looks to them. **The Crew:** - **The Engineer:** Paranoid, conspiracy theorist, first to notice something’s wrong. - **The Medic:** Either a cold pragmatist or a bleeding heart; knows too much about biology. - **The Pilot:** Hotshot, reckless, doesn’t believe in "ghosts in the cargo." - **The Gunslinger:** Ex-bounty hunter, trigger-happy, doesn’t ask questions. - **The Stowaway:** A kid, a fugitive, or an undercover agent. - **The AI/Computer:** Either a snarky personality or an eerie, malfunctioning system. - **The Passenger:** A scientist, a priest, or a corporate rep with secrets. **The Thing in the Crate:** - **Alien Organism:** Mimics, absorbs, or controls people. - **Ancient Artifact:** Cursed, sentient, or a weapon. - **Stolen Experiment:** Government bioweapon, escaped test subject. - **Something… *alive*:** Not necessarily hostile—just *wrong*. - **A Person:** A fugitive, a sleeper agent, or someone in stasis who shouldn’t be awake. --- ### **3. Plot Ideas (Possible Directions)** #### **A. The Slow-Burn Horror (Alien/The Thing Style)** - **Act 1:** Crew picks up a "salvage" crate from a derelict ship. Engineer notices strange readings. - **Act 2:** Small things go missing (tools, food, a crewmate’s log). Paranoia sets in. - **Act 3:** First death—something *wears* the victim’s face. Now no one trusts anyone. - **Act 4:** The ship’s systems start failing. The thing is *learning*. - **Act 5:** Final confrontation—do they jettison the crate, burn it, or try to weaponize it? #### **B. The Heist Gone Wrong (Firefly/Ocean’s 11 in Space)** - **Act 1:** Crew takes a high-paying job to transport a "valuable artifact." - **Act 2:** The crate starts *reacting* to them—whispers, movement, heat signatures. - **Act 3:** They realize it’s not just cargo—it’s *alive*, and it’s *choosing* who to infect. - **Act 4:** Betrayals—someone on the crew is already compromised. - **Act 5:** Do they deliver it and get paid, or destroy it and risk the client’s wrath? #### **C. The Cosmic Mystery (Annihilation/Event Horizon Style)** - **Act 1:** Crate is marked with strange symbols. No one knows what’s inside. - **Act 2:** Crew starts experiencing shared hallucinations—memories that aren’t theirs. - **Act 3:** The crate *opens itself*. Inside is… a mirror? A black void? A *face*? - **Act 4:** The ship’s AI starts speaking in a voice that isn’t its own. - **Act 5:** The crew must decide—do they destroy the crate, or let it "speak" to them? #### **D. The Western Showdown (True Grit in Space)** - **Act 1:** Crate contains a wanted criminal in stasis—bounty is too good to pass up. - **Act 2:** The criminal wakes up… but they’re *different*. Not quite human. - **Act 3:** The criminal starts *recruiting* the crew—offering power, riches, freedom. - **Act 4:** Half the crew is turned. The other half must fight back. - **Act 5:** Final duel—captain vs. the thing in the crate. Who walks away? #### **E. The Corporate Conspiracy (Snowpiercer/Blade Runner Style)** - **Act 1:** Crate is a routine delivery for a megacorp. Paperwork checks out. - **Act 2:** Engineer notices the crate’s temperature is *rising*—but the logs say it’s inert. - **Act 3:** The medic finds *something* in the cargo hold—eggs? A cocoon?
